{"categories": [], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214", "title": "Mail Online"}, "uri": "703083961", "body": "Prince Philip is retiring today aged 96 and has arrived for what is believed to be his 22,220th - and last - official public engagement.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh met Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace who have completed a mammoth 1,664 mile trek on Wednesday - his final official royal event before he retires from public engagements.\n\nPhilip remains in good health but is getting increasingly frail and understandably can have his energy sapped by the 200-or-so public appearances he makes every year on his own or with his wife the Queen, who will never retire.\n\nUntil today's event he has carried out around 22,219 solo engagements since 1947 and given 5,493 speeches - but has now taken a well-earned retirement with 'Team Windsor' - the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry - set to take on some of his workload.\n\nToday in the grounds of Buckingham Palace, Philip is celebrating the achievements of servicemen who have taken part in the 1664 Global Challenge, a series of strength and endurance feats raising funds and awareness for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh met Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace who have completed a mammoth 1,664 mile trek on Wednesday - his final official royal event before he retires from public engagements.\n\nPrince Philip's recent health scares\n\nPrince Philip has boasted excellent health for a 95-year-old and insists he has not had the flu for more than 40 years.\n\nNot to be cowed by his ill health in recent years, he still enjoys an active life and continues with his carriage driving, which he took up in 1971 after retiring from polo.\n\nIn 1961, the Duke broke a bone in his left ankle in a collision on the polo field.\n\nPolo also left him suffering from arthritis in his right wrist, a condition made worse by shaking many thousands of hands at official function\n\nBut in recent years he has struggled with illness.\n\nDecember 2011: The prince is airlifted to hospital from Sandringham two days before Christmas after suffering chest pains, and undergoes surgery for a blocked coronary artery.\n\nJune 2012: Philip is taken to hospital after developing a urinary infection during the river pageant to mark the Queen's Diamond Jubilee\n\nJune 2013: Philip has abdominal surgery for an undisclosed condition and spends 11 days in hospital, including his 92nd birthday.\n\nDecember 2016: Both the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh suddenly cancel plans to leave London for their festive break in Norfolk after they both come down with heavy colds.\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May he would be retiring from royal engagements after more than 65 years supporting the monarch in her role as head of state and attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nPhilip, 96, was praised at the time for his public service with Prime Minister Theresa May leading the tributes saying he had given the Queen 'steadfast support', while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Duke's 'clear sense of public duty' had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Philip's decision - which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related - came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nThe Duke is known for his quips and over the past few months has been joking about his impending retirement, even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event 'I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs'.\n\nHis life-long friend and relative, Lady Myra Butter, 92, told the Mail previously: 'He always used to say, quite openly, I'm past my sell-by date'.\n\nAnd The Duke of Edinburgh made himself and a crowd of guests roar on May 4, when he announced his own retirement, after mathematician Sir Michael Atiyah stopped him at a St James's Palace event to say: 'I'm sorry to hear you're standing down', to which he replied: 'Well I can't stand up much longer'.\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an end on Wednesday he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up in support of the monarch in her role as head of state.\n\nOn Wednesday, in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace Philip, in his role as Captain General of the Royal Marines, attended a parade to mark the finale of the 1664 Global Challenge.\n\nHis association with the Royal Marines dates back 64 years to June 2, 1953 when he was appointed Captain General in succession to the late King George VI.\n\nThe challenge, which recognises the year 1664 when the Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world raising money for the military unit's charity with a number of ingenious feats.\n\nThe 1,664 mile running challenge began in Plymouth on April 25 with Royal Marines running 16.64 miles a day for 100 days, with the gruelling trek due ending at Buckingham Palace today.\n\nThe Duke is meeting some of the runners including two Royal Marines who have completed the entire distance.\n\nRoyal Marines from around the globe have also been taking part in extreme events including a 34-mile swim underwater and a company of Royal Marines lifting more than 20,000 tonnes and running 10,000 kilometres.\n\nDuke of Edinburgh by numbers (1947-today) Total number of solo engagements - 22,219Total number of solo overseas visits - 637 (Commonwealth countries - 229 visits to 67 countries / other countries 408 visits to 76 countries)Total number of speeches given - 5,496Total number of patronages - 785 organisationsPresentation of colours - 54Number of service appointments - 32Number of books authored - 14\n\nDuring the event Philip will also meet veterans and cadets before receiving the 1664 Global Challenge baton.\n\nThe parade ended with a march past, a royal salute and three cheers for the Captain General.\n\nOver the years Philip has attended many Royal Marines events and in 2014, to mark the Corps' 350th anniversary, the Duke wore his full ceremonial uniform as Captain General to the state opening of parliament.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh has spent 52 days this year carrying out public engagements - more than the Queen and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.\n\nWere Philip not standing down from official duties, he would be likely to end this year having clocked up some 90 days of public events, his lowest total in recent years.\n\nAnalysis by the Press Association has found that the number of days spent by the Duke on duties such as meeting the public and attending ceremonial occasions has declined over the past 15 years.\n\nFrom 2002 to 2006, Philip spent an average of 139 days a year on engagements, compared with 121 days from 2012 to 2016.\n\nLast year, the total was 110 - which was still higher than the number for his grandchildren William (80) and Harry (86) and for William's wife Kate (63).\n\nEven in his final year of public service, the Duke has remained more active than the Queen and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, who have spent 49, 45 and 39 days respectively on engagements.\n\nThe royals who have made the most public appearances so far this year have been the Princess Royal (111), Prince Charles (89) and the Duke of York (69).\n\nPhilip's quietest year in recent times came in 2013, when a two-week stint in hospital recovering from abdominal surgery allowed him to attend only 92 days of engagements.\n\nBy contrast, he clocked up 149 days in the Queen's Golden Jubilee year of 2002, and 165 in her Diamond Jubilee year of 2012.\n\nFor the 92 days spanning May to July 2002, he appeared in public on a total of 67 days, including 15 in succession in June.\n\nAlthough Philip was admitted to hospital in August 2012 with a recurrent bladder infection, he still managed 165 days of public engagements during the year.\n\nThis means he spent the equivalent of nearly every other day touring the country to mark the Diamond Jubilee.\n\nTimeline: The life and times of the Duke of Edinburgh\n\n1930: Prince Philippos of Greece and Denmark was born on June 10 1921\n\nJune 10 1921 - Prince Philippos of Greece and Denmark is born to Prince Andrew of Greece and Princess Alice of Battenberg in the family home, Mon Repos, on Corfu. He is the youngest of five children.\n\nDecember 1922 - Eighteen-month-old Prince Philip, travelling in a makeshift cot made from an orange box, is evacuated from Greece on a Royal Navy ship after King Constantine I is forced to abdicate.\n\n1923 - The family settles in the outskirts of Paris. But Princess Alice begins to suffer mental health problems and her religious beliefs become more eccentric.\n\n1928 - At the age of eight Philip travels to England to live with his grandmother and his uncle.\n\n1930 - Philip's mother Princess Alice is diagnosed with schizophrenia and committed to a sanatorium in Switzerland for two years. His father Prince Andrew heads to the French Riviera. Philip is sent to Cheam Preparatory School in the UK.\n\n1933 - At the age of 12 he spends two terms at Salem School in south Germany, run by Kurt Hahn, who inspired Philip to set up the Duke of Edinburgh's Award.\n\n1934 - Philip starts at Gordonstoun School in Morayshire , where he thrived and became head boy and captain of hockey and cricket.\n\nNovember 1934 - Prince Philip and Princess Elizabeth both attend the wedding of Philip's cousin Princess Marina to Elizabeth's uncle George, Duke of Kent, at Westminster Abbey.\n\n1936 - George V dies and is succeeded by his son Edward VIII, who abdicates 11 months later in December 1936 because of his love for American divorcee Wallis Simpson.\n\nMay 1937 - Coronation of George VI - Princess Elizabeth watches her father be crowned king. Philip is among the congregation.\n\nNovember 1937 - Prince Philip attends the funeral in Germany of his sister Cecilie, who was killed in a plane crash at the age of 26.\n\nMay 1939 - In the run-up to the start of the Second World War, Philip finishes at Gordonstoun and begins his naval career at the Britannia Royal Naval College in Dartmouth, where he wins two prizes for being the best cadet.\n\nJuly 1939 - A young Princess Elizabeth falls in love with Philip when he escorts her and her sister Princess Margaret during a tour of the college.\n\n1940 - Philip joins the battleship HMS Ramillies in 1940 in Colombo as a midshipman and spends six months in the Indian Ocean.\n\nJanuary 1941 - He serves on the HMS Valiant in Alexandria and two months later is mentioned in despatches for his actions during the Second World War in the Battle of Matapan after spotting an unexpected enemy vessel with the search lights. He is later awarded the Greek War Cross of Valour.\n\n1942 - Philip rises through the ranks and becomes one of the youngest officers in the Royal Navy to be made First Lieutenant and second-in-command of a ship - HMS Wallace.\n\n1943 - HMS Wallace is despatched to the Mediterranean and provides cover for the Canadian beachhead of the Allied landings in Sicily.\n\n1943 - Prince Philip stays with the Royal Family a number of times during home leave and, after a Christmas visit, Princess Elizabeth places a photograph of him on her dressing table.\n\nFebruary 1944 - Philip is appointed First Lieutenant and second in command of the new Fleet Destroyer HMS Whelp, which sails to the Indian Ocean to join the British Pacific Fleet.\n\nSeptember 2 1945 - Philip is in Tokyo Bay when the Japanese surrender.\n\n1948: Duke of Edinburgh at an event in Windsor\n\n1946 - Philip returns to the UK, spending time at naval training schools. He asks George VI for Princess Elizabeth's hand in marriage.\n\nFebruary 29 1947 - Philip renounces his rights to the Greek throne and becomes a British subject - Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten.\n\nJuly 9 1947 - The engagement of Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten to Princess Elizabeth is announced.\n\nNovember 20 1947 - Philip marries Princess Elizabeth at Westminster Abbey. He is made the Duke of Edinburgh, Earl of Merioneth and Baron Greenwich shortly before his wedding.\n\nOctober 1948 - The Duke attends the Royal Naval Staff College at Greenwich.\n\nNovember 14 1948 - The Duke becomes a father when Princess Elizabeth gives birth to their first child - a son and future king - Prince Charles.\n\n1949 - Philip is appointed First Lieutenant and second-in-command of HMS Chequers, operating from Malta with the Mediterranean fleet.\n\n1950 - He is promoted to Lieutenant-Commander and then appointed in command of the frigate HMS Magpie in Malta.\n\nOctober 21 1950 - Philip and Elizabeth's second child, Princess Anne, is born.\n\n1951 - The Duke and Princess Elizabeth return home from Malta to Clarence House. Philip leaves the Navy prematurely because of the deteriorating health of King George VI and Princess Elizabeth is required to take on more royal responsibilities.\n\n1951 - Princess Elizabeth and Philip make their first major tour together to Canada and the United States in October and November 1951, after which the Duke is made a Privy Counsellor.\n\nFebruary 6 1952 - George VI dies and Princess Elizabeth becomes Queen while in Kenya on a Commonwealth tour.\n\nJune 2 1953 - The Queen's Coronation at Westminster Abbey. The Duke of Edinburgh swore to be his wife's 'liege man of life and limb' and was the first layman to pay tender homage to the newly crowned monarch.\n\n1953:\n\n1956: The Duke of Edinburgh shaking hands with Manchester City's Footballer of the Year Bert Trautmann at Wembley\n\n1956 - The Duke launches the Duke of Edinburgh's Award. The Duke tours the Commonwealth on the royal yacht Britannia, without the Queen.\n\nFebruary 1957 - The Queen gives the Duke the style and title of a Prince of the United Kingdom.\n\nFebruary 1960 - Prince Andrew is born.\n\n1961 - The Duke becomes the first President of the World Wildlife Fund-UK, becoming its international president in 1981. But his shooting of a tiger while in India sparks criticism.\n\n1964 - Prince Edward is born.\n\n1971 - Duke gives up polo, but goes on to take up carriage driving.\n\n1977 - The Queen's Silver Jubilee - 25 years on the throne.\n\n1977: Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh during the State Opening of Parliament in Bridgetown, Barbados, during her Silver Jubilee tour of the Caribbea\n\n1981 - Prince Charles marries Lady Diana Spencer.\n\n1982 - Prince William - a future king - is born and Prince Andrew comes back safely from the Falklands War.\n\n1984 - Prince Harry is born.\n\n1986 - The Duke makes a remark about 'slitty eyes' on a state visit to China. The Queen celebrates her 60th birthday.\n\n1986 - Prince Andrew marries Sarah Ferguson.\n\n1992 - The Queen's 'annus horribilis' - The Princess Royal and Captain Phillips divorce, the Prince and Princess of Wales and the Duke and Duchess of York separate and Windsor Castle is hit by a fire.\n\n1993 - The Queen starts to pay income tax to the Government.\n\n1996 - The Prince of Wales divorces Diana, Princess of Wales. The Duke and Duchess of York divorce.\n\nAugust 31 1997 - Diana, Princess of Wales dies in a car crash.\n\n1997: The Duke of Edinburgh at the Aga Khan School in Bilphok, North West Frontier Province, Pakistan\n\nNovember 20 1997 - The Queen and the Duke's Golden Wedding anniversary.\n\nApril 1999 - A busy and demanding schedule did take its toll sometimes. While accompanying the Queen on a state visit to South Korea, Philip falls asleep at a banquet.\n\n2000 - A new millennium and the Queen Mother's 100th year.\n\n2002 - The Queen's Golden Jubilee - 50 years on the throne. The Queen's younger sister Princess Margaret and the Queen Mother die.\n\n2002 - Philip asks an Aborigine if they still throw spears at each other during a tour of Australia.\n\n2005 - The Prince of Wales marries Camilla Parker Bowles.\n\n2007 - The Queen and the Duke celebrate their Diamond Wedding anniversary.\n\nApril 2008 - The Duke is admitted to hospital with a chest infection that forces him to cancel a number of engagements. He spends three nights in the private King Edward VII's Hospital.\n\n2009 - The Duke becomes the longest serving royal consort in British history, overtaking Queen Charlotte, the wife of King George III.\n\n2010 - Buckingham Palace announces Philip will step down as patron or president of more than a dozen organisations when he turns 90.\n\nDecember 2010 - The Duke becomes a great-grandfather for the first time with the arrival of Peter and Autumn Phillips's daughter Savannah.\n\nApril 2011 - Prince William marries Kate Middleton at Westminster Abbey. The Queen visits Ireland.\n\nJune 2011 - The Duke celebrates his 90th birthday. The Queen gives him a new title - Lord High Admiral, titular head of the Royal Navy.\n\n2017: Prince Philip on May 31 - after he announced his retirement\n\nChristmas 2011 - The Duke is rushed to hospital by helicopter after suffering chest pains. He spends four nights in hospital including Christmas Day and is treated for a blocked coronary artery at Papworth Hospital in Cambridgeshire.\n\n2012 - The Queen's Diamond Jubilee. The Duke is forced to miss the majority of the celebrations when he falls ill with a bladder infection.\n\nAugust 2012 - Philip is treated for a bladder infection once again and spends five nights in hospital in Aberdeen, missing the opening of the Paralympic Games.\n\nJune 2013 - Two days after the service to mark the 60th anniversary of the Queen's coronation, he is hospitalised for an operation on his abdomen and spends two months recuperating.\n\nJuly 2013 - The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's son Prince George is born - third in line to the throne, a future king and the Duke's great-grandson.\n\nMay 2015 - Philip and the Queen's great-granddaughter Princess Charlotte of Cambridge is born.\n\nSeptember 2015 - The Queen becomes the longest reigning monarch in British history.\n\nApril 2016 - The Queen celebrates her 90th birthday.\n\nJune 2016 - Philip turns 95 - his birthday coincides with a weekend of festivities for the Queen's official 90th birthday.\n\nOctober 2016 - The Queen becomes the longest reigning still serving monarch in the world after the death of the Thai king.\n\nFebruary 2017 - The Queen reaches her Sapphire Jubilee - 65 years on the throne.\n\nMay 4 2017 - Buckingham Palace announces that Philip is to step down from public duties.\n\nSeventy years and 22,191 engagements: How Prince Philip has been the Queen's 'rock' since their fairytale wedding, becoming one of the hardest working royals well into his 90s\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh has been the Queen's steadfast companion for nearly 70 years.\n\nKnown for his no-nonsense approach and acerbic wit, Prince Philip is the longest-serving consort in British history and also the oldest serving partner of a reigning monarch.\n\nThe husband of one of the most famous women in the world, he is defined by his relationship to Elizabeth II and gave up a promising naval career to support his wife in her royal role.\n\nWhile the Queen takes centre stage, Philip has always been one step behind, ready to lend a hand.\n\nThe Duke has had a profound effect on the development of the British monarchy and has been a moderniser of 'the Firm'.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh has been the Queen's steadfast companion for nearly 70 years and he has dedicated his life to supporting her - but has decided to step back from his\n\nPhilip has supported his wife throughout her reign. Pictured left at Buckingham Palace on December 8, 2016; right, in his regalia in 1958\n\nThe Queen and the Duke on a farm at their Balmoral estate to celebrate their Silver wedding anniversary in 1972\n\nThe Duke has immersed himself in national life but also served in the Armed Forces, left, in his naval uniform circa 1982; and right, on a boat in Malta in 1949\n\nIn private, he is head of the family. To the public, he is the irascible figure who speaks his mind despite the consequences - famed for his outrageous gaffes.\n\nHe once warned a group of Scottish students in China that they would become 'slitty-eyed'.\n\nIn a Glasgow factory, he pointed to a fusebox of loose wires and remarked that it looked like it had been installed by an 'Indian'.\n\nHe fought for Britain during the Second World War, serving with distinction in the Royal Navy.\n\nAs a younger man he was a good shot, a first-class polo player, accomplished sailor, enthusiastic cricketer and international four-in-hand carriage driver.\n\nHardworking and inquisitive, he has dedicated himself to national life for decades and even when he gave up some of his charitable associations when he was 90, he has still been associated with more than 800 charities.\n\nPrince Philip of Greece and Denmark was born on the island of Corfu on June 10 1921 to Prince Andrew of Greece and Princess Alice of Battenburg.\n\nHis early years were marked by upheaval after his family went into exile following a military coup in Greece which overthrew his uncle, King Constantine I.\n\nGeorge V, the Queen's grandfather, ordered the Royal Navy cruiser HMS Calypso to evacuate the family and Philip was carried to safety in a cot made from an orange box on December 1922, aged just 18 months.\n\nHis childhood lacked stability and he moved between relatives in France and Britain, and started studying at Cheam Prep School in 1928.\n\nHis parent split up and he rarely saw either of them - with his mother, who suffered from mental illlness, being confined to an asylum.\n\nmore videos 1 2 3 Watch video\n\nCar seen in flames on M11 following collision with lorry\n\nWatch video\n\nMoment Linda Hoey is caught out walking without a Elizabeth II as they stand on the balcony of Buckingham Palace shortly after her Coronation\n\nThe couple pictured at the State Opening of Parliament in the House of Lords in 2014, which he has always attended and is likely to continue to do so\n\nmore videos 1 2 3 Watch video\n\nFestival-goer lies motionless after brutal rugby tackle\n\nWatch video\n\nInpatient driver can't wait for ferry to dock roundabout\n\nWatch video\n\nBrave young woman strides into gang fight to save teenager\n\nWatch video\n\nThis is one of the last videos shared by Risila Binte Wazer\n\nWatch video\n\nCar seen in flames on M11 following collision with lorry\n\nWatch video\n\nPassengers alarmed as 700 tonne ferry crashes into harbour\n\nWatch video\n\nMoment Linda Hoey is caught out walking without a disability\n\nAfter spending a year at a school in Germany, he eventually went to Gordonstoun School in Morayshire.\n\nPhilip later joined the Royal Navy and, while a cadet, he caught the eye of a 13-year-old Princess Elizabeth - a distant cousin - when she visited the Britannia Royal Naval College in Dartmouth with her parents, the King and Queen.\n\nDuring the Second World War, he saw active service from the Indian Ocean to the Mediterranean, and by 1945 was in Tokyo Bay as the Japanese surrendered.\n\nHe was mentioned in despatches for his service on battleship HMS Valiant in 1941.\n\nOver the years his friendship with Princess Elizabeth grew and blossomed into love. In 1947, two years after the end of the war, the Princess married dashing, blond Philip in Westminster Abbey.\n\nHe renounced his Greek title and became a naturalised British subject, and was made Duke of Edinburgh by the King.\n\nThe Duke and the Princess had the first of their four children, Charles, now the Prince of Wales, in 1948 and Anne, now the Princess Royal, in 1950.\n\nThey initially enjoyed a simple married life during stays on the island of Malta, where the Duke was stationed with the Navy.\n\nBut their marital bliss changed forever when George VI died on February 6 1952 and Princess Elizabeth became Queen.\n\nPhilip - whose naval career had come to an end - had to a define a new role for himself as his wife diligently took to her duties as head of state.\n\nHe accompanied the Queen around the world on Commonwealth tours and state visits and across the UK.\n\nHe also undertook many solo royal engagements on his own, becoming involved with hundreds of organisations - often as a hands-on president, and continued to do so over the decades.\n\nHe set about modernising Buckingham Palace after being told to keep out of the Queen's official duties, and reorganised the Balmoral and Sandringham estates, as well as becoming ranger of Windsor Great Park.\n\n'I tried to find useful things to do,' he said about starting a footman training programme at the Palace.\n\nIn 1956, he set up the Duke of Edinburgh's Award - inspired by his time at Gordonstoun and his mentor and headmaster Dr Kurt Hahn.\n\nIt has become one of the country's best-known youth self-improvement schemes, with million across the globe gaining their bronze, silver and gold awards.\n\nThe Duke takes a great interest in scientific and technological research and development, as well as the conservation of nature.\n\nAfter a gap of 10 years, the Queen and Philip welcomed two more children - Andrew, now the Duke of York, in 1960, and Edward, now the Earl of Wessex, in 1964.\n\nThe Duke has been depicted as a tough but caring father.\n\nmore videos 1 2 3 Watch video\n\nCar seen in flames on M11 following collision with lorry\n\nWatch video\n\nGang of screaming chimpanzees launch attack to dethrone alpha male\n\nWatch video\n\nDaredevils climb the tallest rollercoaster in England - the Big One\n\nWatch video\n\nTourist coach squeezes past camper van on dangerous Scottish road\n\nWatch video\n\nA \u00a316 tool is used to break into any van in 30 seconds\n\nWatch video\n\nAdorable baby girl has best reaction to hearing Beyonce\n\nWatch video\n\nCrashed cars left abandoned at Britain's worst roundabout\n\nWatch video\n\nBrave young woman strides into gang fight to save teenager\n\nWatch video\n\nThis is one of the last videos shared by Risila Binte Wazer\n\nWatch video\n\n'It's a complete wind up' Agnew's hilarious prank on Boycott\n\nWatch video\n\nVideo shows holidaymakers in huge passport queue at Palma airport\n\nWatch video\n\n'British' jihadi threatens to kill Americans in their own homes\n\nBorn at the family home, Mon Repos in Corfu Greece - allegedly on the kitchen table - on June 10 1921, Philip came to Britain when he was just one year old (pictured in July 2012)\n\nPrince Philip of Greece (second left) with his schoolmates at the MacJannet American school in St Cloud, France in 1929\n\nA keen sportsman, the young prince is pictured here at school during an athletics championship\n\nPhilip waterskiis off Marmaris, Turkey, during the Mediterranean Fleet's summer cruise while serving on HMS Magpie in 1951\n\nmore videos 1 2 3 Watch video\n\nPassengers alarmed as 700 tonne ferry crashes into harbour\n\nWatch video\n\nClip shows Trump greeting children before speaking at podium\n\nWatch video\n\nMoment Linda Hoey is caught out walking without a disability\n\nWatch video\n\nFestival-goer lies motionless after brutal rugby tackle\n\nWatch video\n\nInpatient driver can't wait for ferry to dock and drives into sea\n\nWatch video\n\nShocking moment man BITES and tries to rip police dog's ear off\n\nWatch video\n\nCar seen in flames on M11 following collision with lorry\n\nWatch video\n\nVideo shows holidaymakers in huge passport queue at Palma airport\n\nWatch video\n\nCouple with child make lucky escape as car crashes around them\n\nWatch video\n\nGang of screaming chimpanzees launch attack to dethrone alpha male\n\nWatch video\n\nDaredevils climb the tallest rollercoaster in England - the Big One\n\nWatch video\n\nTourist coach squeezes past camper van on dangerous Scottish road\n\nAn accomplished sportsman, he played polo regularly until 1971 and then took up four-in-hand carriage driving, representing Britain at several European and world championships.\n\nA qualified pilot, he gained his RAF wings in 1953, helicopter wings in 1956 and private pilot's licence in 1959. His love of the sea never waned, and he competing regularly at Cowes Regatta.\n\nThe Duke witnessed first-hand the troubles faced by the Windsors in the 1990s - from the scandal surrounding Sarah, Duchess of York - who was caught having her toes sucked by her financial adviser - to the fall out of Charles and Diana's War of the Waleses.\n\nWhen the Princess of Wales died suddenly in a car crash in 1997, Philip joined Charles, Princes William and Harry, and Diana's brother, Earl Spencer, in the solemn procession behind her funeral cortege.\n\nThe Duke also helped the Queen through the deaths of both her mother and sister in the Golden Jubilee year of 2002.\n\nHe has enjoyed good health throughout much of his life - recovering from a blocked coronary artery in 2011 and a bladder infection in 2012 - the latter leading him to miss the majority of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee celebrations.\n\nHe continued to take part in fast-paced, dangerous carriage-driving events, competing at international level until the age of 85.\n\nmore videos 1 2 3 Watch video\n\nCar seen in flames on M11 following collision with lorry\n\nWatch video\n\nMoment Linda Hoey is caught out walking without a disability\n\nWatch video\n\nFestival-goer lies motionless after brutal rugby tackle\n\nWatch video\n\nInpatient driver can't wait for ferry to dock and drives into sea\n\nWatch video\n\nVideo shows holidaymakers in huge passport queue at Palma airport\n\nWatch video\n\nPassengers alarmed as 700 tonne ferry crashes into harbour\n\nWatch video\n\nClip shows Trump greeting children before speaking at podium\n\nWatch video\n\nShocking moment man BITES and tries to rip police dog's ear off\n\nWatch video\n\nAirport ground staff caught throwing suitcases onto luggage belt\n\nWatch video\n\nPalma airport chaos: Guard shortage leads to 'ridiculous' scene\n\nWatch video\n\nWhite House communications director Anthony Scaramucci is removed from post\n\nWatch video\n\nThis is one of the last videos shared by Risila Binte Wazer\n\nWhen Princess Diana died suddenly in a car crash in 1997, Philip joined Charles, William, Harry and the Princess's brother, Earl Spencer, in the solemn procession behind her funeral cortege\n\nIn August 2012, the Duke was treated for a bladder infection and spent five nights in hospital in Aberdeen and missed the opening of the Paralympic Games. He is pictured leaving the hospital\n\nWhen he turned 90 in June 2011 he insisted on no fuss, but the Queen bestowed on him a new title - Lord High Admiral, titular head of the Royal Navy.\n\nIt was a touching tribute to the man who given up his military career to support his wife, and devote himself to royal service.\n\nA symbol of continuity within the monarchy and public life, the Duke of Edinburgh is the person the Queen relies upon above all others.\n\nPhilip's first ever private secretary Michael Parker, a friend from the Navy, once revealed: 'He told me the first day he offered me my job that his job, first, second and last was never to let her down.'\n\nAs Prince Philip retires aged 96, his wife the Queen will still work full time aged 91 because hers is a 'job for life'\n\nPrince Philip and the Queen arrive at St James's Palace, London, for an Order of Merit service on May shortly after announcing his own retirement\n\nWhile the Duke of Edinburgh is retiring at the grand old age of 96, the Queen is in her job for life.\n\nThe monarch's public duties and behind-the-scenes work as head of state continue despite the Queen being 91.\n\nOn the throne for more than 65 years, Elizabeth II has always made clear it that abdication is not an option.\n\nOn her 21st birthday, she made her now famous radio broadcast from Cape Town in South Africa in 1947 on her first official overseas visit, declaring: 'My whole life, whether it be long or short, shall be devoted to your service and the service of our great imperial family to which we all belong.'\n\nWith Philip stepping down from public duties, the Queen will increasingly turn to younger members of Team Windsor - namely the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Cambridge - to support her in her role.\n\nWilliam's job as an air ambulance pilot finished at the end of July - neatly timed for him to become a full-time royal just before his grandfather retires.\n\nThe Queen rarely carries out overseas duties and, although she still holds investitures, a number are also carried out by Charles, William and the Princess Royal.\n\nBuckingham Palace confirmed: 'Her Majesty will continue to carry out a full programme of official engagements with the support of members of the Royal Family.'\n\nPhilip, however, may pop up at public events from time to time.\n\nHe could choose to make appearances on the Palace balcony for Trooping the Colour in future years or even turn up to greet US president Donald Trump during his proposed state visit.\n\nIn 1992, the Queen dismissed any speculation that she would step down, insisting frankly: 'It is a job for life.'\n\nShe was speaking about the death of her father, King George VI, for a BBC TV documentary, Elizabeth R, marking the 40th anniversary of her accession.\n\n'In a way, I didn't have an apprenticeship. My father died much too young and so it was all very sudden ... taking on and making the best job you can,' the Queen said.\n\n'It's a question of maturing into something that one's got used to doing, and accepting the fact that it's your fate, because I think continuity is very important. It is a job for life.'\n\n'I declare this thing open, whatever it is': The gaffe-prone Duke who often says what he shouldn't (but the public love him for it)\n\nAt times witty, at other times, insensitive, Prince Philip has become known for being the most gaffe-prone member of the Royal Family, not shy of expressing his uncensored and often politically incorrect opinions on a variety of subjects.\n\nThe Queen's 95-year-old husband, who has announced he will retire from royal duties in the Autumn, is renowned for his risque, off-the-cuff remarks while carrying out official engagements.\n\nFrom addressing Aborigines on a state visit to Australia in March 2002 and asking them if they 'still throw spears at one another', to asking singer Tom Jones if he 'gargled with pebbles' following the 1969 Royal Variety performance, his comments have been toe curling and hilarious in equal measures.\n\nHere are some of them:\n\n'British women can't cook' (in Britain in 1966).\n\n'What do you gargle with, pebbles?' (speaking to singer Tom Jones after the 1969 Royal Variety Performance).\n\n'I declare this thing open, whatever it is.' (on a visit to Canada in 1969).\n\n'Everybody was saying we must have more leisure. Now they are complaining they are unemployed' (during the 1981 recession).\n\nIn a state visit to Australia in March 2002, the Prince asked Aborigines: 'Do you still throw spears at each other?' Cultural park manager William Brim replied: 'No, we don't do that any more'\n\n'If it has got four legs and it is not a chair, if it has got two wings and it flies but is not an aeroplane, and if it swims and it is not a submarine, the Cantonese will eat it.' (at a 1986 World Wildlife Fund meeting).\n\n'It looks like a tart's bedroom.' (on seeing plans for the Duke and Duchess of York's house at Sunninghill Park in 1988)\n\n'Yak, yak, yak; come on get a move on.' (shouted from the deck of Britannia in Belize in 1994 to the Queen who was chatting to her hosts on the quayside).\n\n'We didn't have counsellors rushing around every time somebody let off a gun, asking 'Are you all right? Are you sure you don't have a ghastly problem?' You just got on with it.' (about the Second World War commenting on modern stress counselling for servicemen in 1995).\n\n'How do you keep the natives off the booze long enough to get them through the test?' (to a driving instructor in Oban, Scotland, during a 1995 walkabout).\n\n'If a cricketer, for instance, suddenly decided to go into a school and batter a lot of people to death with a cricket bat, which he could do very easily, I mean, are you going to ban cricket bats?' (in 1996, amid calls to ban firearms after the Dunblane shooting).\n\nIn one of his most infamous outbursts, the Duke of Edinburgh said that British students would become 'slitty-eyed' if they stayed in China. The state visit in 1986 became renowned for the incident, after he advised the youngsters: 'If you stay here much longer you will all be slitty-eyed'. In a BBC documentary to mark his 90th birthday, he remarked: 'I'd forgotten about it. But for one particular reporter who overheard it, it wouldn't have come out'\n\n'Bloody silly fool!' (in 1997, referring to a Cambridge University car park attendant who did not recognise him).\n\n'It looks as if it was put in by an Indian.' (pointing at an old-fashioned fusebox in a factory near Edinburgh in 1999).\n\n'Deaf? If you are near there, no wonder you are deaf.' (to young deaf people in Cardiff, in 1999, referring to a school's steel band).\n\n'They must be out of their minds.' (in the Solomon Islands, in 1982, when he was told that the annual population growth was 5%).\n\n'You are a woman, aren't you?' (In Kenya, in 1984, after accepting a small gift from a local woman).\n\n'If you stay here much longer, you'll all be slitty-eyed.' (to British students in China, during the 1986 state visit).\n\nIn 2013, spotting pretty Hannah Jackson, 25, on a trip with his wife to Bromley in Kent, the elderly royal turned to the policeman standing next to her and gestured towards her eye-catching peplum-style red dress which had a zip running the length of its front. 'I would get arrested if I unzipped that dress!' he exclaimed\n\n'Your country is one of the most notorious centres of trading in endangered species in the world.' (in Thailand, in 1991, after accepting a conservation award).\n\n'Oh no, I might catch some ghastly disease.' (in Australia, in 1992, when asked to stroke a Koala bear).\n\n'You can't have been here that long - you haven't got a pot belly.' (to a Briton in Budapest, Hungary, in 1993).\n\n'Aren't most of you descended from pirates?' (to a wealthy islander in the Cayman Islands in 1994).\n\n'You managed not to get eaten, then?' (suggesting to a student in 1998 who had been trekking in Papua New Guinea that tribes there were still cannibals).\n\nIn Germany, in 1997, he welcomed German Chancellor Helmut Kohl at a trade fair as 'Reichskanzler' - the last German leader who used the title was Adolf Hitler.\n\nRoyal quip: The Duke of Edinburgh told this Filipino nurse at Luton and Dunstable University Hospital her country must be 'half empty', because so many of her compatriots have come to the UK to work for the NHS\n\n'You're too fat to be an astronaut.' (to 13-year-old Andrew Adams who told Philip he wanted to go into space. Salford, 2001).\n\n'I wish he'd turn the microphone off.' (muttered at the Royal Variety Performance as he watched Sir Elton John perform, 2001).\n\n'Do you still throw spears at each other?' (In Australia in 2002 talking to a successful aborigine entrepreneur).\n\n'You look like a suicide bomber.' (to a young female officer wearing a bullet-proof vest on Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, in 2002).\n\n'Do you know they're now producing eating dogs for anorexics?' (to a blind woman outside Exeter Cathedral, 2002)\n\nWhile visiting a London community centre group in July 2015, Philip asked a group of women 'who do you sponge off?' Ms Zamir, who founded the Chadwell Heath Asian Women's Network which meets at the centre, said: 'The Duke said to us 'who do you sponge off?' We're all married so it's our husbands. He was just teasing and it's similar to what I call my husband - the wallet'\n\n'Well, you didn't design your beard too well, did you?' (to designer Stephen Judge about his tiny goatee beard in July 2009).\n\n'There's a lot of your family in tonight.' (after looking at the name badge of businessman Atul Patel at a Palace reception for British Indians in October 2009).\n\n'Do you work it a strip club?' (to 24-year-old Barnstaple Sea Cadet Elizabeth Rendle when she told him she also worked in a nightclub in March 2010).\n\n'Do you have a pair of knickers made out of this?' pointing to some tartan (to Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie a papal reception in Edinburgh in September 2010).\n\n'Bits are beginning to drop off.' (on approaching his 90th birthday, 2011)\n\n'How many people have you knocked over this morning on that thing?' (meeting disabled David Miller who drives a mobility scooter at the Valentine Mansion in Redbridge in March 2012)\n\nAt a 400-strong Buckingham Palace reception for British Indians in October 2009, Prince Philip told Indian businessman Atul Patel: 'There's a lot of your family in tonight'. The Prince is pictured during the night\n\n'I would get arrested if I unzipped that dress.' (to 25-year-old council worker Hannah Jackson, who was wearing a dress with a zip running the length of its front, on a Jubilee visit to Bromley, Kent, in May 2012)\n\n'The Philippines must be half empty as you're all here running the NHS.' (on meeting a Filipino nurse at a Luton hospital in February 2013)\n\n'Most stripping is done by hand.' (to 83-year-old Mars factory worker Audrey Cook when discussing how she used to strip or cut Mars Bars by hand in April 2013)\n\n'(Children) go to school because their parents don't want them in the house.' (prompting giggles from Malala Yousafzai, who survived an assassination attempt by the Taliban after campaigning for the right of girls to go to school without fear - October 2013)\n\n'Just take the f***ing picture.' (losing patience with an RAF photographer at events to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain - July 2015)\n\n'You look starved.' (to a pensioner on a visit to the Charterhouse almshouse for elderly men - February 2017)\n\nIn 2015 an impatient Prince Philip was caught on camera during a photocall for the Battle of Britain and appeared to say: 'Just take the f***ing picture'\n\nOther quotes:\n\n'I'm just a bloody amoeba.' (on the Queen's decision that their children should be called Windsor, not Mountbatten).'Gentlemen, I think it is time we pulled our fingers out.'(to the Industrial Co-Partnership Association on Britain's inefficient industries in 1961).'Are you asking me if the Queen is going to die?' (on being questioned on when the Prince of Wales would succeed to the throne)'If the man had succeeded in abducting Anne, she would have given him a hell of a time while in captivity.' (On a gunman who tried to kidnap the Princess Royal in 1974).'I hope he breaks his bloody neck.' (when a photographer covering a royal visit to India fell out of a tree)'If it doesn't fart or eat hay, she's not interested.' (on the Princess Royal)'When a man opens a car door for his wife, it's either a new car or a new wife.' (on marriage).'It's a pleasant change to be in a country that isn't ruled by its people.' (to Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan dictator).'Where did you get that hat?' "eng", "source": {"uri": "coventrytelegraph.net", "id": "2070", "title": "coventrytelegraph"}, "uri": "703022161", "body": "Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh will meet Royal Marines who have completed a mammoth 1,664 mile trek on Wednesday - his final official royal event before he retires from public engagements.\n\nIn the grounds of Buckingham Palace, Philip will celebrate the achievements of servicemen who have taken part in the 1664 Global Challenge, a series of strength and endurance feats raising funds and awareness for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May he would be retiring from royal engagements after more than 65 years supporting the monarch in her role as head of state and attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nPhilip, 96, was praised at the time for his public service with Prime Minister Theresa May leading the tributes saying he had given the Queen \"steadfast support\", while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Duke's \"clear sense of public duty\" had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Philip's decision - which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related - came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nThe Duke is known for his quips and over the past few months has been joking about his impending retirement, even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event \"I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs\".\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an end on Wednesday he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up in support of the monarch in her role as head of state.\n\nOn Wednesday, in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace Philip, in his role as Captain General of the Royal Marines, will attend a parade to mark the finale of the 1664 Global Challenge.\n\nHis association with the Royal Marines dates back 64 years to June 2, 1953 when he was appointed Captain General in succession to the late King George VI.\n\nThe challenge, which recognises the year 1664 when the Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world raising money for the military unit's charity with a number of ingenious feats.\n\nThe 1,664 mile running challenge began in Plymouth on April 25 with Royal Marines running 16.64 miles a day for 100 days, with the gruelling trek due to end at Buckingham Palace on Wednesday.\n\nThe Duke will meet some of the runners including two Royal Marines who have completed the entire distance.\n\nRoyal Marines from around the globe have also been taking part in extreme events including a 34-mile swim underwater and a company of Royal Marines lifting more than 20,000 tonnes and running 10,000 kilometres.\n\nDuring the event Philip will also meet veterans and cadets before receiving the 1664 Global Challenge baton.\n\nThe parade will end with a march past, a royal salute and three cheers for the Captain General.\n\nOver the years Philip has attended many Royal Marines events and in 2014, to mark the Corps' 350th anniversary, the Duke wore his full ceremonial uniform as Captain General to the state opening of parliament.\n\nRead More Wednesday's must-read stories\n\nDownload our all-new mobile app to get the latest news, sport and what's on.\n\nOne quick sync and you can read our content on the move without being online.\n\nGet regular news alerts straight to your mobile and keep up with the latest traffic and travel or breaking events as they happen via our daily live blogs.\n\nIt's completely customisable to your own specific interests.\n\nDownload it today by clicking here for iPhone and here for Android\n\nLooking for an older story? duty\" had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Philip's decision - which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related - came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nThe Duke is known for his quips and over the past few months has been joking about his impending retirement, even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event \"I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs\".\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an end on Wednesday he {"categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges_and_Universities", "label": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges and Universities", "id": 143, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "bbc.co.uk", "id": "264", "title": "BBC News"}, "uri": "702913888", "body": "The Queen's husband Prince Philip will take part in his final public meeting before he officially retires from royal duties.\n\nThe 96-year-old announced his retirement in May, after decades of supporting the Queen, as well as attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nPrince Philip is also known as the Duke of Edinburgh, but who is he and why is he so important?\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh is the Queen's husband - they've been married for nearly 70 years.\n\nThey met while Prince Philip was an officer in the Navy during World War Two.\n\nHe and the Queen have four children: Prince Charles, Prince Andrew, Prince Edward and Princess Anne.\n\nPrince Philip is also the grandfather of Princes William and Harry, and the great-grandfather of Prince George and Princess Charlotte.\n\nAlthough he isn't the king, his job title is pretty special. He's the Queen's 'consort' - and his role is to support Queen Elizabeth II.\n\nHe now holds the record for the longest-serving consort in British history!\n\nPrince Philip was born in 1921 on the Greek island of Corfu.\n\nHis family left Greece when Philip was just a one-year-old baby.\n\nHe spent his childhood in France, Germany and then here in Britain.\n\nHe celebrated his 96th birthday in June 2017.\n\nPhilip gave up his job in the Navy after Queen Elizabeth II's father died and she became Queen.\n\nHe has always thrown himself into his role of supporting her and has found a real passion in doing charity work.\n\nOne issue he cares about a lot is wildlife conservation - something he spoke to Newsround about back in 1986.\n\nYou may also have heard of one of his most important and famous charities: The Duke of Edinburgh Award scheme.\n\nIt offers challenges and adventure to thousands of young people in the UK.\n\nSince the Duke of Edinburgh's Award was launched in 1956, millions of young people have taken part in the scheme.\n\nPhilip also has a reputation for speaking his mind, and sometimes his comments have caused some people embarrassment.\n\nHowever, he is also praised by many for his dedication and his unique way of doing things.\n\nThe Queen is not only the head of state of the UK but she's also Head of the Commonwealth - an association of 52 countries, many of which used to be part of the British Empire.\n\nAs well as visiting parts of the UK, part of the Queen's job involves visiting these other countries, meeting people and doing lots of charity work, which Prince Philip often helps her with.\n\nSince 1952, Prince Philip has completed 22,219 royal engagements on his own.\n\nEvery year the Royal Family carry out over 2,000 official visits throughout the UK and worldwide.\n\nAs the Queen and the Duke have become older more of these royal duties have been passed to the younger members of the family.\n\nWhile Prince Philip's diary of events will come to an end in August, Buckingham Palace has said he may still decide to attend certain events alongside the Queen in the future.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule will continue as {"categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges_and_Universities", "label": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges and Universities", "id": 143, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "inquisitr.com", "id": "2639", "title": "The Inquisitr News"}, "uri": "703158893", "body": "Prince Philip is one tough cookie, as he survives yet another \"death\" announced by the media. In a massively erroneous report, the Daily Telegraph published an incomplete article online on Wednesday, announcing the Duke of Edinburgh's passing.\n\nThe Guardian reported, that the article, which has since been taken down, read: \"The Duke of Edinburgh, the longest-serving consort to a monarch in British history, has died at the age of XX, Buckingham Palace has announced.\"\n\nThe incomplete article further read: \"He will be given a royal ceremonial funeral in line with his wishes, which is expected to take place in seven days' time.\"\n\nA spokesman for the Telegraph apologized for the mistake and said that publishing processes will be reviewed as a matter of urgency. Meanwhile, this is not the first time that Prince Philip has been prematurely announced as dead. Back in May, the Sun made a similar error when the Duke had first announced his retirement from public engagements. The article, which was swiftly removed after publication online, was titled \"Prince Philip dead at 95, how did the Duke of Edinburgh die, etc etc.\"\n\nThe Telegraph's incomplete article was published online on Wednesday, as the still-alive Prince Philip prepared for his final day of public engagements. The 96-year-old monarch has accomplished 22,219 solo engagements since 1952. According to the Guardian, Buckingham Palace staff has calculated the Prince's solo overseas visits to be at 637. He has visited 143 countries, delivered 5,496 speeches, and has carried out the role of patron for 785 organizations during his royal career. On top of all that, he still managed to write 14 books.\n\nOn Wednesday, in the grounds of Buckingham Palace, Prince Philip met Royal Marines who have completed a mammoth 1,664-mile trek. This is his final official Royal event before he withdraws from public engagements. The Prince celebrated the achievements of servicemen who have taken part in the 1664 Global Challenge, which was a series of strength and endurance feats aimed to raise funds and awareness for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nBut perhaps, the Duke of Edinburgh is best known for his seemingly never-ending list of gaffes during his reign as Queen Elizabeth II's husband. Throughout his career, his public appearances were not devoid of controversy. The Independent compiled some of his most popular gaffes.\n\nIn 1986, he told 21-year-old British student Simon Kerby during his visit to China: \"If you stay here much longer, you will go home with slitty eyes.\"\n\nIf his comments were uttered at a much later time, when every thing you say can be easily judged on the Internet, it would probably be a cause for outrage as most of his comments border on racism. For example, when he said to a woman in Kenya in 1984 after accepting a gift, \"You ARE a woman, aren't you?\"\n\n\"It looks as though it was put in by an Indian,\" the Prince once said of a fuse box during a tour of a Scottish factory in 1999. Later on, he clarified his comment and said, \"I meant to say cowboys. I just got my cowboys and Indians mixed up.\"\n\nWhile on a visit in 1998, Prince Philip also said to a British student who had trekked to Papua New Guinea, \"You managed not to get eaten then?\"\n\nMeanwhile, the Queen will continue with her duties and public schedule, and will be supported by other members of the royal family.", "eventUri": "eng-3330847", "isDuplicate": false, During the challenge, which kicked off April 24 and wrapped up Aug. 2, Royal Marines from around the world took part in various events (such as one company running 10,000 kilometers over the course of 20 days) to fundraise for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nDuring the festivities, the Prince Philip took the royal salute and met veterans and members of the Royal Marine's Association -- of which he has been honorary president since 1948.\n\nHe was also met with cheers as he was handed the Challenge baton. Watch footage from the event here:\n\nPhilip's wife, Queen Elizabeth, wasn't in attendance due to a prior commitment, but this won't be the last opportunity to see Philip by her side. He has also authored 14 books, has given 5,496 speeches, and served as patron to 785 organizations.\n\nRELATED: More Details on Prince Philip's Retirement\n\nOnce he retires, Philip is expected to After a lifetime of public service by the side of his wife Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip will finally retire on Wednesday (Aug 2) at the age of 96.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh will attend a parade of Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace, the last of 22,219 solo public engagements since the queen ascended to the throne in 1952.\n\nHe has attended countless more events with the queen, now 91, but both have slowed their pace in recent years, handing over responsibilities to the younger royals.\n\n\"Prince Philip is entitled to slow down a bit,\" the Daily Telegraph newspaper wrote in an editorial. \"This is a man who has always put his country first.\"\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nThe former World War II naval officer has carried out 637 overseas visits on his own in the past 65 years, given almost 5,500 speeches, and was patron, president or a member of more than 780 organisations.\n\nHis final engagement on Wednesday will honour his military background, as he attends the end of a charity challenge in which Royal Marines ran 2,678km over 100 days to mark the founding of the commando force in 1664.\n\nPrince Philip has been captain general of the corps since 1953, taking over from the queen's father King George VI, who had died the year before.\n\nThe queen has described her husband of almost 70 years, who is now the longest-serving consort in British history, as \"my strength and stay\".\n\nBut after announcing his plans to retire in May, he joked that he was the \"world's most experienced plaque-unveiler\".\n\nThe prince's often politically incorrect sense of humour has got him into trouble in the past, although for many of the queen's subjects, it has also provided some welcome warmth into the institution of the monarchy.\n\n\"Humour is important. The Duke's has brightened these decades,\" the Telegraph said.\n\nPrince Philip is still in good health for a man of his age, although he was hospitalised for two nights in June for the treatment of an undisclosed infection.\n\nA spokesman said Prince Philip's individual programme of public engagements had come to an end, but \"he may choose to attend engagements alongside the queen from time to time\".\n\nWhen he announced his retirement, Prime Minister Theresa May offered him Britain's \"deepest gratitude and good wishes\".\n\nBoth the senior royals have taken a step back in recent years, leaving their eldest son and heir Prince Charles and grandson Prince William to take their places.\n\nPrince William, the Duke of Cambridge, ended his brief career as an air ambulance pilot last week and will now turn his full attention to royal duties, alongside his wife Kate.\n\nBut while the queen supports her husband's decision to retire, experts say her own sacred vow at her coronation to serve for life was unbreakable.\n\n\"Her Majesty will continue to carry out a full programme of official engagements with the support of members of the royal family,\" the palace said earlier this "eng", "source": {"uri": "spaldingtoday.co.uk", "id": "3818", "title": "Spalding Guardian"}, "uri": "702458563", "body": "The Duke of Edinburgh will meet Royal Marines who have completed a mammoth 1,664 mile trek on Wednesday - his final official royal event before he retires from public engagements.\n\nIn the grounds of Buckingham Palace Philip will celebrate the achievements of servicemen who have taken part in the 1664 Global Challenge, a series of strength and endurance feats raising funds and awareness for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May he would be retiring from royal engagements after more than 65 years supporting the monarch in her role as head of state and attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh to attend Royal Marines' Parade at Buckingham Palace to mark @RM1664Challenge finale. https://t.co/t1V9hn54KW pic.twitter.com/6Dhr6QE86H\n\n-- The Royal Family (@RoyalFamily) July 25, 2017\n\nPhilip, 96, was praised at the time for his public service with Prime Minister Theresa May leading the tributes saying he had given the Queen \"steadfast support\", while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Duke's \"clear sense of public duty\" had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Philip's decision - which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related - came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nThe Duke is known for his quips and over the past few months has been joking about his impending retirement, even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event \"I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs\".\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an end on Wednesday he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up in support of the monarch in her role as head of state.\n\nOn Wednesday in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace Philip, in his role as Captain General of the Royal Marines, will attend a parade to mark the finale of the 1664 Global Challenge.\n\nHis association with the Royal Marines dates back 64 years to June 2, 1953 when he was appointed Captain General in succession to the late King George VI.\n\nThe challenge, which recognises the year 1664 when the Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world raising money for the military unit's charity with a number of ingenious feats.\n\nThe 1,664 mile running challenge began in Plymouth on April 25 with Royal Marines running 16.64 miles a day for 100 days, with the gruelling trek due to end at Buckingham Palace on Wednesday.\n\nThe Duke will meet some of the runners including two Royal Marines who have completed the entire distance.\n\nRoyal Marines from around the globe have also been taking part in extreme events including a 34-mile swim underwater and a company of Royal Marines lifting more than 20,000 tonnes and running 10,000 kilometres.\n\nCopyright (c) Press Association Ltd. 2017, All "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Christianity", "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Christianity", "id": 253, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Maritime", "id": 288, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Vehicles/Watercraft", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Vehicles/Watercraft", "id": 456, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "id": "17001", "title": "The Scottish Sun"}, "uri": "703141762", "body": "He has made us chuckle and cringe during his 70 years as the Queen's companion\n\nTHE Duke of Edinburgh left his final solo royal engagement to the tune of For He's A Jolly Good Fellow as he entered retirement after 65 years.\n\nMarking the end of an era, Prince Philip was hailed as \"historic\" by senior officers who described the 96-year-old as a \"wonderful figurehead for all Royal Marines to look up to\".\n\nSoldiers cheered Hip Hip Hooray as he lifted his hat in the air at the end of his last official event at Buckingham Palace.\n\nThe retiring royal didn't let the bad weather dampen his spirits as he waved to crowds who had turned out to see him at his last event in the pouring rain.\n\nThe former Royal Navy officer has attended 22,219 solo engagements and 637 overseas tours since 1952 in a career marked by his famous gaffes.\n\nHe has spent the past few months joking about his impending retirement - even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event \"I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs\".\n\nToday the Duke celebrated the achievements of servicemen in the grounds of Buckingham Palace, after they completed a mammoth 1,664 mile trek for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nHe laughed with senior officers as he marked the end of an impressive 65 years championing his own causes and charities.\n\nIn May the Queen's Consort announced he would be retiring from royal engagements after more than 65 years supporting the monarch in her role as head of state and attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nPhilip, 96, was praised at the time for his public service with Prime Minister Theresa May leading the tributes saying he had given the Queen \"steadfast support'', while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Duke's ''clear sense of public duty'' had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Philip's decision - which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related - came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an end on Wednesday he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up in support of the monarch in her role as head of state.\n\nToday the Duke, in his role as Captain General of the Royal Marines, met some of the runners including two Royal Marines who have completed the 1664 Global Challenge.\n\nHis association with the Royal Marines dates back 64 years to June 2, 1953 when he was appointed Captain General in succession to the late King George VI.\n\nThe challenge, which recognises the year 1664 when the Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world raising money for the military unit's charity with a number of ingenious feats.\n\nThe 1,664 mile running challenge began in Plymouth on April 25 with Royal Marines running 16.64 miles a day for 100 days, with the gruelling trek due to end at Buckingham Palace on Wednesday.\n\nCpl Thompson, from Carlisle, today said: \"This is historic because this is the Duke's last royal engagement and we're a part of it, the Royal Marines are a part of it - so it's an absolute honour.\"\n\nLieutenant Colonel Gary Green, who devised the 1664 Global Challenge, said: \"It's an honour for the Armed Forces having the Duke of Edinburgh's last public engagement with the Corps and the Royal Navy - it's brilliant, we're delighted.\"\n\nHe added: \"The Duke of Edinburgh is all about challenges, he's all about charity work and helping people and having somebody like the Duke as head of the Royal Marines, it just helps the Corps with our own challenges.\n\n\"With somebody who's head of the Corps, who's quite exceptional in what he does, it makes the Corps exceptional, it builds our Commando spirit and he's a wonderful figurehead for all Royal Marines to look up to.\"\n\nRoyal Marines from around the globe have also been taking part in extreme events including a 34-mile swim underwater and a company of Royal Marines lifting more than 20,000 tonnes and running 10,000 kilometres.\n\nDuring the event Philip will also meet veterans and cadets before receiving the 1664 Global Challenge baton.\n\nThe parade will end with a march past, a royal salute and three cheers for the Captain General.\n\nOver the years Philip has attended many Royal Marines events and in 2014, to mark the Corps' 350th anniversary, the Duke wore his full ceremonial uniform as Captain General to the state opening of parliament.", "eventUri": "eng-3330847", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2017-08-02", "title": "Prince "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges_and_Universities", "label": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges and Universities", "id": 143, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nst.com.my", "id": "5690", "title": "New Straits Times Online"}, "uri": "702991351", "body": "LONDON: After a lifetime of public service by the side of his wife Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip will finally retire on Wednesday at the age of 96.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh will attend a parade of Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace, the last of 22,219 solo public engagements since she ascended to the throne in 1952.\n\nHe has attended countless more events with the queen, now 91, but both have slowed their pace in recent years, handing over responsibilities to the younger royals.\n\n\"Prince Philip is entitled to slow down a bit,\" the Daily Telegraph newspaper wrote in an editorial, adding: \"This is a man who has always put his country first.\"\n\nThe former World War II naval officer has carried out 637 overseas visits on his own in the past 65 years, given almost 5,500 speeches, and was patron, president or a member of more than 780 organisations.\n\nHis final engagement on Wednesday will honour his military background, as he attends the end of a charity challenge in which Royal Marines ran 1,664 miles over 100 days to mark the founding of the commando force in 1664.\n\nPhilip has been captain general of the corps since 1953, taking over from the queen's father king George VI, who had died the year before.\n\nThe queen has described Philip, her husband of almost 70 years who is now the longest-serving consort in British history, as \"my strength and stay.\"\n\nBut after announcing his plans to retire in May, he joked he was the \"world's most experienced plaque-unveiler.\"\n\nThe prince's often politically incorrect sense of humour has got him into trouble in the past, although for many of the queen's subjects, it has also provided some welcome warmth into the institution of the monarchy.\n\n\"Humour is important. The Duke's has brightened these decades,\" the Telegraph said.\n\nPhilip is still in good health for a man of his age, although he was hospitalised for two nights in June for the treatment of an undisclosed infection.\n\nA spokeswoman said his individual programme of public engagements had come to an end, but \"he may choose to attend engagements alongside the queen from time to time.\"\n\nWhen he announced his retirement, Prime Minister Theresa May offered him Britain's \"deepest gratitude and good wishes.\"\n\nBoth the senior royals have taken a step back in recent years, leaving their eldest son and heir Prince Charles and grandson Prince William to take their places.\n\nWilliam, the Duke of Cambridge, ended his brief career as an air ambulance pilot last week and will now turn his full attention to royal duties, alongside his wife Kate.\n\nBut while the queen supports her husband's decision to retire, experts say her own sacred vow at her 1953 coronation to serve for life was unbreakable.\n\n\"Her Majesty will continue to carry out a full programme of official engagements with the support of members of the royal family,\" the palace said earlier this After a lifetime of public service by the side of his wife, Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip will finally retire on Wednesday at the age of 96.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh will attend a parade of Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace, the last of 22,219 solo public engagements since she ascended to the throne in 1952.\n\nHe has attended countless more events with the queen, now 91, but both have slowed their pace in recent years, handing over responsibilities to the younger royals.\n\n\"Prince Philip is entitled to slow down a bit,\" the Daily Telegraph newspaper wrote in an editorial, adding: \"This is a man who has always put his country first.\"\n\nThe former World War II naval officer has carried out 637 overseas visits on his own in the past 65 years, given almost 5,500 speeches, and was patron, president or a member of more than 780 organizations.\n\nHis final engagement on Wednesday will honor his military background, as he attends the end of a charity challenge in which Royal Marines ran 1,664 miles over 100 days to mark the founding of the commando force in 1664.\n\nPhilip has been captain general of the corps since 1953, taking over from the queen's father, King George VI, who had died the year before.\n\nThe queen has described Philip, her husband of almost 70 years who is now the longest-serving consort in British history, as \"my strength and stay.\n\nBut after announcing his plans to retire in May, he joked he was the \"world's most experienced plaque-unveiler.\n\nThe prince's often politically incorrect sense of humor has got him into trouble in the past, although for many of the queen's subjects, it has also provided some welcome warmth into the institution of the monarchy.\n\n\"Humour is important. The Duke's has brightened these decades,\" the Telegraph said.\n\nPhilip is still in good health for a man of his age, although he was hospitalized for two nights in June for the treatment of an undisclosed infection.\n\nA spokeswoman said his individual program of public engagements had come to an end, but \"he may choose to attend engagements alongside the queen from time to time.\n\nWhen he announced his retirement, Prime Minister Theresa May offered him Britain's \"deepest gratitude and good wishes.\n\nBoth the senior royals have taken a step back in recent years, leaving their eldest son and heir, Prince Charles, and grandson, Prince William, to take their places.\n\nWilliam, the Duke of Cambridge, ended his brief career as an air ambulance pilot last week and will now turn his full attention to royal duties, alongside his wife Kate.\n\nBut while the queen supports her husband's decision to retire, experts say her own sacred vow at her 1953 coronation to serve for life was unbreakable.\n\n\"Her Majesty will continue to carry out a full program of official engagements with the support of members of the royal family,\" the palace said earlier this year.", "eventUri": In taking this decision, The Duke has the full support of The Queen.\n\n\"Prince Philip will attend previously scheduled engagements between now and August, both individually and accompanying The Queen.\n\n\"Thereafter, The Duke will not be accepting new invitations for visits and engagements, although he may still choose to attend certain public events from time to time.\n\n\"The Duke of Edinburgh is Patron, President or a member of over 780 organisations, with which he will continue to be associated, although he will no longer play an active role by attending engagements.\"", number of ingenious feats.\n\nThe 1,664 mile running challenge began in Plymouth on April 25 with Royal Marines running 16.64 miles a day for 100 days, with the gruelling trek due to end at Buckingham Palace on Wednesday.\n\nThe Duke will meet some of the runners including two Royal Marines who have completed the entire distance.\n\nRoyal Marines from around the globe have also been taking part in anything less.\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh is known for his public gaffes, and has made a series of off-the-cuff comments over the years - ranging from hilarious to very politically incorrect.\n\nAs he bowed out of public life, at the grand old age of 96, the Duke couldn't resist one last joke.\n\nAnd let's face it, after carrying out 22,219 solo engagements since 1952, one is going to need a good sense of humour.\n\nSpeaking to the Royal Marines and referring to their fundraising efforts, he joked: \"You should all be locked up.\"\n\nThe Duke was attending a parade of Royal Marines, where he was meeting servicemen who have taken part in a 1,664 mile race to raise money for the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nDespite bad weather, many still flocked to outside the Palace to peek through the fence railings at the significant moment in royal history.\n\nWearing a black bowler hat and a long coat to stay dry, the Duke appeared in good spirits during the event when Royal Marines marched past him.\n\nThe Mirror's royal reporter Victoria Murphy tweeted from the event: \"Spontaneous cheers from the crowds and a final wave from Prince Philip as his last engagement comes to a close.\"\n\nIt's definitely not the first time Prince Philip has made jokes during public events.\n\nAfter being told that Madonna was singing the Die Another Day theme in 2002: \"Are we going to need ear plugs?\"\n\nSpeaking to a female sea cadet, he once asked: \"Do you work in a strip club?\"\n\nAnd referring to singer Tom Jones back in 1969, he quipped: \"It's difficult to see how it's possible to become immensely valuable by singing what are the most hideous songs.\"\n\nRead more of Prince Philip's best (and worst) public gaffes in the link below.\n\nThe engagement was hailed as \"historic\" by a Royal Marine whose feat of strength and endurance was celebrated by the retiring royal.\n\nAs a former Royal Navy officer Philip's last official event, after almost 70 years championing his own causes and charities, fittingly featured men from the Royal Marines - an integral part of the Navy.\n\nThe Duke was praised for his role as Captain General of the Royal Marines by a senior officer who described the 96-year-old as a \"wonderful figurehead for all Royal Marines to look up to\".\n\nThe event marked the end of the 1664 Global Challenge, a series of exploits that have pushed marines from the Corps to their physical limits in aid of the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nThe challenge, which recognises 1664, the year the Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world fundraising, including Corporal Will Gingell, 33, and Corporal Jamie Thompson, 31, who have run 1,664 miles over 100 days.\n\nCpl Thompson, from Carlisle but based in Plymouth, whose epic marathon ended earlier, said: \"This is historic because this is the Duke's last royal engagement and we're a part of it, the Royal Marines are a part of it - so it's an absolute honour.\"\n\nThe Queen's The Daily Telegraph published an incomplete article online Wednesday announcing Philip's death as the still-alive prince prepared for his final day of public engagements.\n\nThe story appeared on the newspaper's website and it read: \"The Duke of Edinburgh, the longest-serving consort to a monarch in British history, has died at the age of XX, Buckingham Palace has announced. \"Prince Philip, whom the Queen described as her 'strength and stay' during her record-breaking reign, passed away XXXXXXX.\"\n\nThe story coincided with the Duke's last public engagements before he retires Wednesday.\n\nRead: 10 Funniest Quotes To Celebrate Prince Philip's Birthday\n\nA note at the top of the article also read: \"This file needs to be a living file - and will serve Apple News as well as be the main news story. Please stick to the format below.\"\n\nTwitter users had a field day as the Telegraph made this blunder, which is not the first in the news industry. The Sun made a similar error in May when it announced that Prince Philip would be retiring from public engagements.\n\nWhile many mocked the publication for repeating the Sun's error, others tried to figure out what the Prince's reaction would be if he read the article about his death.\n\nIn what will be Philip's final engagement, he will pay tribute to those who have taken part in a 1,664 Global Challenge, which is a series of strength and endurance feats to raise funds and awareness for the Royal Marines charity.
