'Unacceptable': New Zealand Labour leader asked about baby plans\n\nJacinda Ardern, the new leader of the New Zealand Labour Party, has slammed a radio show host's comments that employers should know women's baby plans before hiring them. Vision courtesy Newshub.\n\nUp Next Drones: The future of delivery? Drones: The future of delivery? Drones: The future of delivery?\n\nAn Estonian company is testing futuristic drink delivery methods by using drones to supply cold drinks to beach goers.\n\nUp Next Suicide attackers grenade Shi'te mosque Suicide attackers grenade Shi'te mosque Suicide attackers grenade Shi'te mosque\n\nNo one has yet claimed responsibility for a suicide attack on a Shi'ite mosque in the western Afghan city of Herat which has killed more than 29 people and wounded more than 64.\n\nUp Next Inmates used peanut butter to escape jail Inmates used peanut butter to escape jail Inmates used peanut butter to escape jail\n\nAuthorities say 12 inmates who broke out of a county jail in Alabama used peanut butter to disguise the numbers on a cell door and fool guards to make their getaway.\n\nMore videos Prince Philip, Queen's most loyal subject, retiring\n\nPrince Philip, known for his constant support of the Queen of England as well as his occasional gaffes, will retire from royal duties later this year.\n\nThis is to be his 22,219th official solo engagement since 1952, the year his wife became Queen.\n\nIt is to be his last. As announced in May (after a brief media panic when rumours spread he had died overnight), he has decided he will no longer carry out public engagements.\n\nRelated Articles Prince Philip hospitalised due to infection Social media a big hit for Queen's 91st celebrations\n\nThe symbolism of his last appointment is likely no coincidence. Captain General is one of his oldest duties, passed to him in June 1953 from his father-in-law, King George VI. It is reportedly now going to Prince Harry.\n\nIt will be marked in a very British way. After the Duke meets veteran and cadet Marines, the parade ends with a march, a Royal Salute - and \"three cheers for the Captain General\".\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Palace stresses Prince Philip is not going to disappear altogether. He will still accompany the Queen on occasion, and may choose to attend \"certain public events from time to time\". He will also keep up some official duties including correspondence.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nBut, essentially, this marks the retirement of Britain's longest-serving consort.\n\nThe royal household has calculated he took part in 637 solo overseas visits, gave 5496 speeches and wrote 14 books. He is patron of 785 organisations.\n\nHe has made more public appearances this year than either the Queen or the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge: 51 since January. In 2016 he was the fifth busiest royal.\n\nThe Duke will soon head up to Balmoral with the Queen for their annual summer holiday.\n\nAfter that, he is expected to spend most of his time at Windsor. Locals and visitors may catch sight of him whizzing about Windsor Great Park on antique royal carriages - his hobby, which he took up after giving up polo age 50.\n\nOther hobbies include oil painting, reading and photography.\n\nHe's not the type of man to put his feet up, Dickie Arbiter, the Queen's press secretary until 2000, told The Sun.\n\n\"He'll still be involved in something even if just from his office, from phone calls and talking to his patronages, talking to his charities, maybe even visiting them on a private visit.\n\n\"He's not giving up life, he's just stepping back from full-time public engagement and taking it a bit easier.\"\n\nHistorian Christopher Lee told the BBC the prince was the first man in Buckingham Palace to put computers in his office.\n\n\"He will want to know about the big issues. He will know every single touch, nuance on Brexit, for example. He is briefed on everybody he is likely to meet, even people he will never meet and he takes it in.\n\n\"I think he's never stopped being an admiral. Admirals are like that, they have to be, and admirals never retire.\"\n\nThe Duke has had several health scares in recent years: he spent two nights in hospital in June with an infection, missing the State Opening of Parliament and the last two days of Royal Ascot.\n\nIn 2008 he spent three days in hospital with a serious chest infection, in late 2011 he suffered chest pains and had heart surgery.\n\nIn 2012 during the Queen's diamond jubilee celebrations he suffered a bladder infection that put him in hospital for almost a week. The problem recurred later in the year.\n\nThen in 2013 he was admitted to hospital for 11 days for exploratory surgery on his abdomen.\n\nRoyal watchers say one reason for his retirement was he feared growing frail in public, and told close friends \"I'm past my sell-by date\".\n\nBut he is generally in good health for his age.\n\nHe was born on June 10, 1921 in the Greek island of Corfu, the fifth child of Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark, and Princess Alice of Battenburg.\n\nHis childhood was unsettled, as Greece went through political upheaval. Age 18 he began a naval career, serving in World War II, and ended active service in 1951, just before the Queen's coronation.\n\nPrince Philip and the Queen, distant cousins, were first friends then fell in love. They married in November 1947.\n\nIn 2015 he became the last person to be awarded an Australian knighthood, in the controversial and short-lived resurrection of the imperial-style honour by then prime minister Tony Abbott.\n\nHe has many other orders and titles - including lord high admiral of the Royal Navy, an appointment given to him by the Queen as a 90th birthday present.\n\nOver the years he has also been well-known for his gaffes - politically incorrect jokes that risked offence.\n\nIn 1966 he commented that \"British women can't cook\"; in 1986 he warned British students in China they might become \"slitty-eyed\"; and in 2002 he asked an indigenous Australian if they \"still throw spears at each other\". In 2013 he told Malala Yousafzai that children \"go to school because their parents don't want them in the house\".\n\nHe once said of Princess Anne, \"if it doesn't fart or eat hay, she's not interested\".\n\nBut he is loved by the public for his unswerving support for the Queen.\n\nAt their golden wedding anniversary in 1997 she described him as \"someone who doesn't take easily to compliments, but he has, quite simply, been my strength and stay all these years, and I and his whole family, in this and many other countries, owe him a debt greater than he would ever claim or we As announced in May (after a brief media panic when rumours spread he had died overnight), he has decided he will no longer carry out public engagements.\n\nRelated Articles Prince Philip hospitalised due to infection Social media a big hit for Queen's 91st celebrations\n\nThe symbolism of his last appointment is likely no coincidence. Captain General is one of his oldest duties, passed to him in June 1953 from his father-in-law, King George VI. It is reportedly now going to Prince Harry.\n\nIt will be marked in a very British way. After the Duke meets veteran and cadet Marines, the parade ends with a march, a Royal Salute - and \"three cheers for the Captain General\".\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Palace stresses Prince Philip is not going to disappear altogether. He will still accompany the Queen on occasion, and may choose to attend \"certain public events from time to time\". He will also keep up some official duties including correspondence.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nBut, essentially, this marks the retirement of Britain's longest-serving consort.\n\nThe royal household has calculated he took part in 637 solo overseas visits, gave 5496 speeches and wrote 14 books. He is patron of 785 organisations.\n\nHe has made more public appearances this year than either the Queen or the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge: 51 since January. In 2016 he was the fifth busiest royal.\n\nThe Duke will soon head up to Balmoral with the Queen for their annual summer holiday.\n\nAfter that, he is expected to spend most of his time at Windsor. Locals and visitors may catch sight of him whizzing about Windsor Great Park on antique royal carriages - his hobby, which he took up after giving up polo age 50.\n\nOther hobbies include oil painting, reading and photography.\n\nHe's not the type of man to put his feet up, Dickie Arbiter, the Queen's press secretary until 2000, told The Sun.\n\n\"He'll still be involved in something even if just from his office, from phone calls and talking to his patronages, talking to his charities, maybe even visiting them on a private visit.\n\n\"He's not giving up life, he's just stepping back from full-time public engagement and taking it a bit easier.\"\n\nHistorian Christopher Lee told the BBC the prince was the first man in Buckingham Palace to put computers in his office.\n\n\"He will want to know about the big issues. He will know every single touch, nuance on Brexit, for example. He is briefed on everybody he is likely to meet, even people he will never meet and he takes it in.\n\n\"I think he's never stopped being an admiral. Admirals are like that, they have to be, and admirals never retire.\"\n\nThe Duke has had several health scares in recent years: he spent two nights in hospital in June with an infection, missing the State Opening of Parliament and the last two days of Royal Ascot.\n\nIn 2008 he spent three days in hospital with a serious chest infection, in late 2011 he suffered chest pains and had heart surgery.\n\nIn 2012 during the Queen's diamond jubilee celebrations he suffered a bladder infection that put him in hospital for almost a week. The problem recurred later in the year.\n\nThen in 2013 he was admitted to hospital for 11 days for exploratory surgery on his abdomen.\n\nRoyal watchers say one reason for his retirement was he feared growing frail in public, and told close friends \"I'm past my sell-by date\".\n\nBut he is generally in good health for his age.\n\nHe was born on June 10, 1921 in the Greek island of Corfu, the fifth child of Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark, and Princess Alice of Battenburg.\n\nHis childhood was unsettled, as Greece went through political upheaval. Age 18 he began a naval career, serving in World War II, and ended active service in 1951, just before the Queen's coronation.\n\nPrince Philip and the Queen, distant cousins, were first friends then fell in love. again laterInvalid Email\n\nThe Duke of Edinburgh, who was attending his final royal engagement today, has made a number of visits to Coventry and Warwickshire over the years.\n\nThe Duke, who was today meeting Royal Marines who have completed a 1,664-mile trek for charity, accompanied the Queen on a visit to the newly opened Warwickshre Justice Centre in 2011.\n\nThey were later greeted by thousands of well-wishers as they arrived in Stratford-upon-Avon to reopen the Royal Shakespeare Theatre following a three-and-a-half year transformation project.\n\nJust over a decade earlier, in 2000, the Duke was in Coventry accompanying the Queen when she attended the Home Front commemoration service in the cathedral ruins.\n\nThe occasion was to recognise the millions of people who volunteered at home in the Second World War.\n\nWhen Prince Philip visited Coventry and Warwickshire View gallery\n\nWhen Prince Philip visited Coventry and Warwickshire\n\nView gallery\n\nThe Queen and Prince Philip also visited the city during the Queen's Silver Jubilee celebrations in 1977 and the former Jaguar factory in Browns Lane in 1994.\n\nThe Duke also accompanied the Queen to lay the foundation stone of the new Coventry Cathedral in 1956 and was with her at its consecration in 1962.\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May that he would be retiring from royal engagements after more than 65 years supporting the monarch in her role as head of state and attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nThe Duke, 96, was praised at the time for his public service with Prime Minister Theresa May leading the tributes saying he had given the Queen \"steadfast support\", while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said his \"clear sense of public duty\" had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Prince Philip's decision - which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related - came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nRead More Wednesday's must-read stories\n\nThe Duke is known for his quips and over the past few months has been joking about his impending retirement, even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event \"I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs\".\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed that although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an today he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up Literally.\n\nOne of Prince Philip's many titles is Captain General of the Royal Marines. On Wednesday afternoon, at Buckingham Palace, the 96-year-old is due to attend a parade marking the finale of the Marines' 1664 Challenge, a series of strength and endurance challenges raising money for charity.\n\nMore World News Videos Previous slide Next slide Prince Philip, Queen's most loyal ... Vision courtesy Newshub.\n\nUp Next Drones: The future of delivery? Drones: The future of delivery? Drones: The future of delivery?\n\nAn Estonian company is testing futuristic drink delivery methods by using drones to supply cold drinks to beach goers.\n\nUp Next Suicide attackers grenade Shi'te mosque Suicide attackers grenade Shi'te mosque Suicide attackers grenade Shi'te mosque\n\nNo one has yet claimed responsibility for a suicide attack on a Shi'ite mosque in the western Afghan city of Herat which has killed more than 29 people and wounded more than 64.\n\nUp Next Inmates used peanut butter to escape jail Inmates used peanut butter to escape jail Inmates used peanut butter to escape jail\n\nAuthorities say 12 inmates who broke out of a county jail in Alabama used peanut butter to disguise the numbers on a cell door and fool guards to make their getaway.\n\nUp Next Hundreds on trial over failed Turkey coup Hundreds on trial over failed Turkey coup Hundreds on trial over failed Turkey coup\n\nNearly 500 suspects are on trial for bombing government buildings and attempting to kill President Recip Tayyip Erdogan in 2016.\n\nMore videos Prince Philip, Queen's most loyal subject, retiring\n\nPrince Philip, known for his constant support of the Queen of England as well as his occasional gaffes, will retire from royal duties later this year.\n\nThis is to be his 22,219th official solo engagement since 1952, the year his wife became Queen.\n\nIt is to be his last. As announced in May (after a brief media panic when rumours spread he had died overnight), he has decided he will no longer carry out public engagements.\n\nRelated Articles Prince Philip hospitalised due to infection Social media a big hit for Queen's 91st celebrations\n\nThe symbolism of his last appointment is likely no coincidence. Captain General is one of his oldest duties, passed to him in June 1953 from his father-in-law, King George VI. It is reportedly now going to Prince Harry.\n\nIt will be marked in a very British way. After the Duke meets veteran and cadet Marines, the parade ends with a march, a Royal Salute - and \"three cheers for the Captain General\".\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Palace stresses Prince Philip is not going to disappear altogether. He will still accompany the Queen on occasion, and may choose to attend \"certain public events from time to time\". He will also keep up some official duties including correspondence.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nBut, essentially, this marks the retirement of Britain's longest-serving consort.\n\nThe royal household has calculated he took part in 637 solo overseas visits, gave 5496 speeches and wrote 14 books. He is patron of 785 organisations.\n\nHe has made more public appearances this year than either the Queen or the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge: 51 since January. In 2016 he was the fifth busiest royal.\n\nThe Duke will soon head up to Balmoral with the Queen for their annual summer holiday.\n\nAfter that, he is expected to spend most of his time at Windsor. Locals and visitors may catch sight of him whizzing about Windsor Great Park on antique royal carriages - his hobby, which he took up after giving up polo age 50.\n\nOther hobbies include oil painting, reading and photography.\n\nHe's not the type of man to put his feet up, Dickie Arbiter, the Queen's press secretary until 2000, told The Sun.\n\n\"He'll still be involved in something even if just from his office, from phone calls and talking to his patronages, talking to his charities, maybe even visiting them on a private visit.\n\n\"He's not giving up life, he's just stepping back from full-time public engagement and taking it a bit easier.\"\n\nHistorian Christopher Lee told the BBC the prince was the first man in Buckingham Palace to put computers in his office.\n\n\"He will want to know about the big issues. He will know every single touch, nuance on Brexit, for example. He is briefed on everybody he is likely to meet, even people he will never meet and he takes it in.\n\n\"I think he's never stopped being an admiral. Admirals are like that, they have to be, and admirals never retire.\"\n\nThe Duke has had several health scares in recent years: he spent two nights in hospital in June with an infection, missing the State Opening of Parliament and the last two days of Royal Ascot.\n\nIn 2008 he spent three days in hospital with a serious chest infection, in late 2011 he suffered chest pains and had heart surgery.\n\nIn 2012 during the Queen's diamond jubilee celebrations he suffered a bladder infection that put him in hospital for almost a week. The problem recurred later in the year.\n\nThen in 2013 he was admitted to hospital for 11 days for exploratory surgery on his abdomen.\n\nRoyal watchers say one reason for his retirement was he feared growing frail in public, and told close friends \"I'm past my sell-by date\".\n\nBut he is generally in good health for his age.\n\nHe was born on June 10, 1921 in the Greek island of Corfu, the fifth child of Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark, and Princess Alice of Battenburg.\n\nHis childhood was unsettled, as Greece went through political upheaval. Age 18 he began a naval career, serving in World War II, and ended active service in 1951, just before the Queen's coronation.\n\nPrince Philip and the Queen, distant cousins, were first friends then fell in love. They married in November 1947.\n\nIn 2015 he became the last person to be awarded an Australian knighthood, in the controversial and short-lived resurrection of the imperial-style honour by then prime minister Tony Abbott.\n\nHe has many other orders and titles - including lord high admiral of the Royal Navy, an appointment given to him by the Queen as a 90th birthday present.\n\nOver the years he has also been well-known for his gaffes - politically incorrect jokes that risked offence.\n\nIn 1966 he commented that \"British women can't cook\"; in 1986 he warned British students in China they might become \"slitty-eyed\"; and in 2002 he asked an indigenous Australian if they \"still throw spears at each other\". In 2013 he told Malala Yousafzai that children \"go to school because their parents don't want them in the house\".\n\nHe once said of Princess Anne, \"if it doesn't fart or eat hay, she's not interested\".\n\nBut he is loved by the public for his unswerving support for the Queen.\n\nAt their golden wedding anniversary in 1997 she described him as \"someone who doesn't take easily to compliments, but he has, quite simply, been my strength and stay all these years, and I and his whole family, in this and many other countries, owe him a debt greater than he would ever claim or we He joined the Royal Navy in 1939, aged 18 and in October of 1942, he became first lieutenant of HMS Wallace at 21 years old - one of the youngest first lieutenants in the Royal Navy.\n\nThe Duke met the then-Princess Elizabeth whilst he was training at the Royal Naval College in Dartmouth when she was just 13, but the pair continued to write to each other once the Princess returned to Windsor.\n\nIn the summer of 1946, Philip asked the King George VI for his daughter's hand in marriage, delaying the public announcement of their engagement until Elizabeth turned 21 the following April. The couple were then married on 20 November 1947 at Westminster Abbey. The day before the wedding, the King bestowed the style of Royal Highness on Philip and on the morning of the wedding, he was made the Duke of Edinburgh as he had abandoned both his Greek and Danish royal titles in order to marry Elizabeth. In 1957, the Queen granted her husband the title of a Prince of the United Kingdom, restoring the royal status that he had formally renounced ten years earlier.\n\nSince the Queen's accession to the throne in 1953, the Duke has supported his wife in her royal duties as sovereign, accompanying her to ceremonies, state dinners, and tours abroad.\n\nPrince Philip has been patron of almost 800 organisations, mainly focused on the environment, industry, sport, and education, in particular serving as Chancellor of the Universities of Cambridge, Edinburgh, Salford and Wales. In 1956, the Duke, with Kurt Hahn, founded the Duke of Edinburgh's Award in order to give young people \"a sense of responsibility to themselves and their communities\". Over the years, he has slowly bestowed theses patronages to his grand children, Prince William and Prince Harry, along with the Duchess of Cambridge, and following a bout of ill health, Kensington Palace announced in May 2017 that the Duke would retire from his royal duties in the following summer.\n\nAs he makes his last royal appearance at the the Captain General's Parade at Buckingham Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world fundraising, including Corporal Will Gingell, 33, and Corporal Jamie Thompson, 31, who have run 1,664 miles over 100 days.\n\nCpl Thompson, from Carlisle but based in Plymouth, whose epic marathon ended earlier, said: \"This is historic because this is the Duke's last royal engagement and we're a part of it, the Royal Marines are a part related.\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements has come to an end he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's an integral part of the Navy.\n\nThe Duke was praised for his role as Captain General of the Royal Marines by a senior officer who described the 96-year-old as a \"wonderful figurehead for all Royal Marines to look up to\".\n\nThe event marked the end of the 1664 Global Challenge, a series of exploits that have pushed marines from the Corps to their physical limits in aid of the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nThe challenge, which recognises 1664, the year the Corps was founded, has seen Royal Marines all over the world fundraising, including Corporal Will Gingell, 33, and Corporal Jamie Thompson, 31, who have run 1,664 miles over 100 days.\n\nCpl Thompson, from Carlisle but based in Plymouth, whose epic marathon ended earlier, said: \"This is historic because this is the Duke's last royal engagement and we're a part of it, the Royal Marines are a part of it - so it's an absolute honour.\"\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May he would be retiring from royal engagements, a decision which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related.\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements has come to an end he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up in support of the monarch in her role as head of state.\n\nHis Royal Highness may still attend events alongside The Queen from time to time. pic.twitter.com/qnamtDptM0 -- The Royal Family (@RoyalFamily)\n\nAugust 2, 2017\n\nThe historic day began with the Duke stood on a dais in the palace's forecourt where he received the royal salute from an honour guard of Royal Marines.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Gary Green, who devised the 1664 Global Challenge, said: \"It's an honour for the Armed Forces having the Duke of Edinburgh's last public engagement with the Corps and the Royal Navy - it's brilliant, we're delighted.\"\n\nHe added: \"The Duke of Edinburgh is all about challenges, he's all about charity work and helping people and having somebody like the Duke as head of the Royal Marines, it just helps the Corps with our own challenges.\n\n\"With somebody who's head of the Corps, who's quite exceptional in what he does, it makes the Corps exceptional, it builds our Commando spirit and he's a wonderful figurehead for all Royal Marines to look up to.\"\n\nAs part of the 1664 Global Challenge Royal Marines from around the globe have also been taking part in extreme events including a 34-mile swim underwater and a company of Royal Marines lifting more than 20,000 tonnes and running 10,000 kilometres.", "eventUri": "eng-3330847", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2017-08-02", "title": "Philip hailed as wonderful figurehead for Royal Marines at final solo engagement", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-02", "id": "14903799", "extractedDates": [{"date": "2017-08-02", "textStart": 1997, "amb": false, "textEnd": 2011}], "storyUri": "eng-3330847", "time": "15:03:00", "details": {}, "concepts": [], "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/philip-hailed-as-wonderful-figurehead-for-royal-marines-at-final-solo-engagement-35991631.html", "timeCrawl": "15:03:00", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/article35991625.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/bpanews_bb413f7a-0f79-4a1b-a115-d5d58e2e8c93_1", "location": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-02T15:03:00Z", "originalArticle": null, "sim": 0.545098066329956}

The elderly Duke of Edinburgh has been struggling with his health for a number of years and the decision to retire from public duties was made at the start of the summer.\n\nHis last engagement - his 22,219th as royal consort - will be a meeting with Royal Marines who have run 16.64 miles per day for 100 days for charity, in reference to the foundation year of the Marines, 1664. He will attend a parade and meet participants in London. Prince Philip is Captain General of the Royal Marines, a title that is expected to pass to his grandson Prince Harry.\n\nCredit: PA\n\nHe began public duties back in 1952, when the Queen acceded to the throne on the death of her father, King George VI.\n\nAs the husband of the monarch - they married in 1947 - he has stood by her side for 70 years and is involved in a huge a range of organisations from the Royal Navy, where he is Lord High Admiral, down to 785 other charities.\n\nHis titular Duke of Edinburgh's Award has been taken by 4 million people across over 100 countries worldwide.\n\nThe 96-year-old consort to the Queen has suffered from a succession of physical issues, including a brief spell in hospital in June, which caused him to miss the State Opening of Parliament. Donald Trump signs 'seriously flawed' Russia sanctions bill\n\nUS President Donald Trump has signed a bill slapping new sanctions on Russia, even as he calls the bill itself \"flawed.\"\n\nMore videos Prince Philip makes final solo engagement\n\nBritain's Prince Philip completes his last public engagement after 65 years of service, meeting a group of Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace.\n\nThere was a march past, there were rows of hundreds of burly serving Marines, veterans and cadets for him to salute him and to chat to.\n\nThere were two rounds of God Save the Queen, a tune he will hear a lot less often from now on.\n\nRelated Articles Kate Middleton is the duchess of outfit repeats Diana: 'Charles was all over me like a bad rash'\n\nThree slightly terrifying \"hip hip hoorays\" from the Marines won them a cheery wave of the hat from their Captain General.\n\nThen he was gone, back inside the palace, probably looking forward to a relaxing afternoon beer (sources say his bitter of choice is Boddingtons).\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJob done.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nThe occasion was a parade marking the finale of the Marines' 1664 Challenge, a series of strength and endurance challenges raising money for charity (said one Marine, \"you get into a zone where nothing hurts any more\").\n\nCaptain General is one of Philip's oldest duties, passed to him in June 1953 from his father-in-law King George VI. His replacement is up to the Queen, though media have speculated it's to be Prince Harry.\n\nPhilip is now retired - he will no longer carry out solo public engagements, though he will still accompany the Queen on occasion, and may choose to attend \"certain public events from time to time\", the palace said.\n\nHe will also keep up some official duties, including correspondence.\n\nIn the crowd outside the palace was Bob Bruce, who served in the Royal Marines for 26 years. He was there with his son, simply to mark the occasion.\n\n\"He's done a long stint,\" Bruce said of Philip. \"He'd turn out to all the important events of the Royal Marines and quite a lot of unimportant events and informal events as well - he's always been a great supporter.\"\n\nBruce said he had met the Duke, briefly, a couple of times.\n\n\"He's fantastic, he's well known as being able to chat with anybody at any level. He's always got a clever comment to make, or a quick humorous quip.\n\n\"He spoke at the 350th anniversary dinner of the Royal Marines [in 2014] when he wasn't expected to speak. He stood up at a moment's notice and had the whole hall in stitches of laughter with his funny stories.\n\n\"I think we're very proud to see him today. He's given great service to the Corps, but he's also given fantastic service to the country.\"\n\nBrigadier Richard Spencer, deputy commandant general of the Royal Marines, said the Marines had been \"hugely privileged\" to have the Duke of Edinburgh as their Captain General.\n\nHe had been much more than a figurehead, the brigadier said, he had been instrumental in drawing together the Corps family, and had provided advice and counsel to 25 commandants-general, the professional heads of the Marines.\n\n\"As always with people of such experience, they have the ability to see through the peaks and troughs of life,\" he said.\n\nAnd Philip had clearly enjoyed the military side to his job - a former naval officer who served in the Second World War, he had also been Admiral of the Fleet and Colonel of the Grenadier Guards.\n\n\"That was particularly evident when you saw him with our cadets and veterans,\" the brigadier said.\n\n\"You saw the sparkle in his eyes and the spring in his "eng", "source": {"uri": "shieldsgazette.com", "id": "746", "title": "Shields Gazette"}, "uri": "703152951", "body": "The Duke of Edinburgh has retired from official royal engagements in his own inimitable style by joking with Royal Marines they should be \"locked up\" for their madcap fundraising efforts.\n\nAs a former Royal Navy officer Philip's last public solo event, after more than 65 years championing his own causes and charities, fittingly featured men from the Royal Marines, an integral part of the Navy.\n\nBut from the demeanour of the Queen's Consort you would never have guessed he was retiring after carrying out 22,219 solo engagements since 1952.\n\nHe waved warmly to the crowds, acknowledging their cheers and was described as \"chirpy\" by a senior officer.\n\nWearing a bowler hat and rain coat the Duke did not let a heavy downpour affect his final day which was staged in Buckingham Palace's forecourt.\n\nThe event marked the end of the 1664 Global Challenge, which recognises 1664, the year the Royal Marines were founded, and has seen marines push themselves to the limit with a series of physical exploits in aid of the Royal Marines Charity.\n\nThe Duke, who is the Captain General of the Royal Marines, met Corporal Will Gingell, 33, and Corporal Jamie Thompson, 31, who have run 1,664 miles over 100 days.\n\nHe also chatted to Sergeant Matt Burley, a physical training instructor, who swam 1,664 lengths underwater over 10 days and Lieutenant Colonel Aldeiy Alderson, who ran 100 kilometres in 12 hours wearing his Royal Marines uniform and polished boots.\n\nLooking at the group of marines he made them laugh with the quip: \"You all should be locked up.\"\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May he would be retiring from royal engagements, a decision which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related.\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed, although the Duke's diary of engagements has come to an end, he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\nThe Queen's public schedule continues as normal but other members of the Royal Family will step up in support of the Over the decades he has become renowned for his stalwart support of his wife, Queen Elizabeth II - and his blunt and sometimes offensive remarks. Here are a few of his memorable quotes:\n\n1969:\n\n\"What do you gargle with, pebbles?\" - to singer Tom Jones.\n\nFILE - In this Thursday, June, 16, 2011 file photo Britain's Queen Elizabeth II with Prince Philip arrive by horse drawn carriage in the parade ring on the third day, traditionally known as Ladies Day, of the Royal Ascot horse race meeting at Ascot, England. Britain's Prince Philip on Wednesday Aug. 2, 2017 retires from solo official duties. Over the decades he has become renowned for his stalwart support of his wife, Queen Elizabeth II. (AP Photo/Alastair Grant, File)\n\n\"I declare this thing open, whatever it is\" - on a visit to Canada.\n\n___\n\n1992:\n\n\"Oh no, I might catch some ghastly disease\" - when asked to stroke a koala in Australia.\n\n___\n\n1995:\n\n\"How do you keep the natives off the booze long enough to pass the test?\" - to a Scottish driving instructor.\n\n___\n\n2000:\n\n\"It's a vast waste of space\" - at a reception for the opening of the new British Embassy in Berlin.\n\n___\n\n2010:\n\n\"Do you have a pair of knickers made out of this?\"- pointing to a tartan and addressing Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie at a papal reception in Edinburgh.\n\nFILE - In this Oct. 17, 1957 file photo President Dwight Eisenhower and first lady Mamie are flanked by their royal guests, Britain's Queen Elizabeth and her husband, Prince Philip, at the White House. Queen Elizabeth II's husband, Prince Philip, will stop carrying out public engagements this fall, Buckingham Palace announced Thursday May 4, 2017. (AP Photo, File)\n\nFILE - In this Wednesday, May 25, 2011 file photo President Barack Obama and first lady Michelle Obama welcome Britain's Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip for a reciprocal dinner at Winfield House in London. Britain's Prince Philip on Wednesday Aug. 2, 2017 retires from solo official duties. Over the decades he has become renowned for his stalwart support of his wife, Queen Elizabeth II. Her husband, Prince Philip, has also been a public fixture for some time - best known in the UK for his ready wit and occasional PC faux-pas - and he has been in the news again lately as a result of a decision to retire from making public trips. Prince Philip has had a series of health scares in recent years, and at the age of 96, it has been decided that he will be bowing out from making public visits.\n\nHowever, this has led to some particularly poor taste mistakes being made in the media. In recent months, as it was initially suggest that the Prince would be bowing out of public engagements, some media outlets accidentally published statements as if he had passed on - similar occurrences emerged regarding former US President George HW Bush. This time, however, it was the turn of British news giant the Telegraph to get the wrong end of the stick - in possible the worst way possible.\n\nAs the Duke of Edinburgh recently made his last engagement, The Telegraph mistakenly announced to readers that the popular figurehead had passed away - in an article that advised his age to be 'XX years'. While the story now redirects to a different story regarding the Prince, the damage was already done - as The Sun will know only too well, having made the same mistake earlier this year, only to linger around on search results for some time afterwards. It is commonplace for famous people to have obituaries lined up in the media - as it allows for a quick and respectful coverage of their passing - but there have been numerous occasions this year of such a mishap taking place.\n\nPrince Philip retires from royal duties having clocked up over 22,000 different engagements purely on his own over the past 65 years - though it will likely not be the last we see of the Duke, as the opportunity is open for him to appear alongside the Queen in future engagements should he wish to do so - and should it be advisable. planet who can hurry her majesty, by snapping: \"Yak yak yak, come on, get a move on\".\n\n\"The Queen is more reserved and shy, whereas Prince Philip is very open and has got this lovely sense of Police officers joked with the hardy few who stood close to the barriers and huddled under their umbrellas.\n\nOne woman turned to her daughter and said: \"We just have to accept we are going to get {"categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Time_Period", "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Time Period", "id": 286, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Military", "label": "dmoz/Society/Military", "id": 287, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Topic", "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Topic", "id": 653, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "vogue.com", "id": "1135", "title": "Vogue"}, "uri": "703155451", "body": "This morning, as a light drizzle descended on Buckingham Palace, Prince Philip officially retired from public life. It's an end of an era: In his nearly 70 years in service, the royal made 22,219 solo engagements, gave 5,496 speeches, wrote 14 books, and visited 143 countries. He holds the record for longest-serving consort in British history.\n\nThe 96-year-old, wearing a trenchcoat and a bowler hat, met with the Royal Marines to commend them on finishing a 1,664-mile journey for charity. In terms of official engagements, it's a low-key one -- it's no, say, Royal Ascot or a star-studded movie premiere. But is the perfect final solo event for Philip.\n\nYou see, the Prince has always been a military man. He joined the Britannia Royal Naval College in 1939 and served throughout World War II, even earning special recognition for his efforts at the Battle of Cape Matapan. He eventually rose through the ranks to become a commander, and moved to Malta with his young bride, the then-Princess Elizabeth, in the late 1940s. It's said that time in Eastern Europe was one of the happiest in their lives.\n\nHis naval career was stopped short upon the ascension of his wife to the throne, but he refused to let that pesky fact get in the way of his military sportsmanship. He got his Royal Air Force Wings in 1953, his helicopter wings in 1956, and his private pilot's license in 1959. And when it came time to become patron to a number of royal organizations (over his lifetime, he would be appointed to 785), he gravitated to many veteran and military organizations . . . including, yes, the Royal Marines, which named him Captain General.\n\nAnd today, did the audience applaud for their captain! When the band played \"For He's a Jolly Good Fellow,\" the marines gave him an enthusiastic three cheers -- a touching response from a usually restrained crowd. He acknowledged it all with a tip of his hat, and when he walked off the stage, he gave one final wave to all who looked on.\n\nPrince Philip likely thought he had more time in the armed forces -- after all, Elizabeth was only 25 when her father died, leaving her as the ruler of the British Empire. But his was still a lifetime of duty: to his people, his country, and his wife, to whom he is the most loyal subject.", "eventUri": "eng-3330847", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2017-08-02", "title": We will be reviewing our publishing processes as a matter of urgency.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a newspaper has prematurely announced Prince Philip's death.\n\nThe Sun made a similar error in May when the duke announced his retirement from public engagements.\n\nThe tabloid published and hastily removed an article titled: \"Prince Philip dead at 95, how did the Duke of Edinburgh die, etc {"categories": [], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "vancouversun.com", "id": "1553", "title": "Vancouver Sun"}, "uri": "703111017", "body": "Queen Elizabeth's coronation on June 2, 1953. At the age of 96, Britain's Prince Philip retires from solo official duties. Over the decades he has become renowned for his stalwart support of his wife -- and his off-the-cuff remarks. Leslie PriestIn this August 1951 file photo, then-Princess Elizabeth stands with her husband Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, and their children Prince Charles and Princess Anne at the couple's London residence at Clarence House.AP PhotoJune 29, 2010: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip leave HMCS St. John's after the International Fleet Review in Halifax, Canada.Chris JacksonOctober 1986: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the Great Wall of ChinaShareAdjustCommentPrint\n\nLONDON \u00e2\u0080\" For over 65 years, he has been the unwavering presence alongside Britain\u00e2\u0080\u0099s longest-serving monarch, the consummate consort and royal representative.\n\nOn Wednesday Prince Philip will make his 22,219th \u00e2\u0080\" and final \u00e2\u0080\" solo public engagement. He will be meeting Royal Marines who have completed a 2,678-kilometre trek to raise money for charity.\n\nAfter that, the Duke of Edinburgh will still appear at Queen Elizabeth II\u00e2\u0080\u0099s side \u00e2\u0080\" from time to time \u00e2\u0080\" as the 91-year-old monarch soldiers on. In the meantime, the man known for his quips and gaffes has already been joking about his big retirement day.\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI\u00e2\u0080\u0099m discovering what it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s like to be on your last legs,\u00e2\u0080\u009d the 96-year-old Philip told celebrity chef Prue Leith at a recent palace event. The palace says his health wasn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t behind the retirement decision.\n\nPhilip, who enjoys a slightly wicked turn of phrase, has poked fun at himself and his advancing years, even referring to himself as the \u00e2\u0080\u009cworld\u00e2\u0080\u0099s most experienced plaque unveiler.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\n\nOver the years, Philip\u00e2\u0080\u0099s also been known to make some blunt and sometimes offensive remarks. When asked to stroke a koala in Australia in 1992, the prince retorted: \u00e2\u0080\u009cOh no, I might catch some ghastly disease.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\u00c2\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cGhastly\u00e2\u0080\u009d seems to be the prince\u00e2\u0080\u0099s go-to adjective. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how he described Beijing in a 1986 tour of China and Elton John\u00e2\u0080\u0099s car, a\u00c2 1978 Aston Martin, in 2001.\u00c2\n\nHere are a few more of his memorable quotes:\n\n1956:\u00c2 \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt is my invariable custom to say something flattering to begin with so that I shall be excused if by any chance I put my foot in it later on.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" in a speech that should have prepared all of us for next 65 years.\u00c2\n\n1969: \u00e2\u0080\u009cI declare this thing open, whatever it is.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" on a visit to Canada.\n\n1984: \u00e2\u0080\u009cYou are a woman, aren\u00e2\u0080\u0099t you?\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" to a native Kenyan woman who gave the prince a small gift.\u00c2\n\n1986: \u00e2\u0080\u009cIf you stay here much longer, you\u00e2\u0080\u0099ll all be slitty-eyed.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" to a group of British students in China.\n\n1995: \u00e2\u0080\u009cHow do you keep the natives off the booze long enough to pass the test?\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" to a Scottish driving instructor.\n\n1997: \u00e2\u0080\u009cDeaf? If you are near there, no wonder you are deaf.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" to a group of deaf children who were near a Jamaican steel drum band.\u00c2\n\n1997: \u00e2\u0080\u009cBloody silly fool!\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" to a parking attendant at Cambridge University who didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t recognize him.\u00c2\n\n2000: \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a vast waste of space.\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\" at a reception for the opening of the new British Embassy in Berlin.\n\n2003: \u00e2\u0080\u009cYou look like you\u00e2\u0080\u0099re ready for with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nThe repercussions of Prince Philip's retirement from royal duties are being felt in ways that you couldn't imagine.\n\nTo mark the occasion, Legoland has retired a tiny 10cm figure of the Duke of Edinburgh from its Lego display of Buckingham Palace.\n\nLego recalled 120,000 sets because one worker packed the wrong shade of grey\n\nBut first, one important tweak had to be made - the addition of Philip's now famous bowler hat that he wore for his last public engagement, a meeting with Royal Marines in the grounds of the palace.\n\nAn even tinier Lego hat was placed in the tiny Duke's Lego hand - and workers even added a 'Gone Fishing' sign on the gate of Miniland's Buckingham Palace.\n\nA Legoland spokeswoman said: 'The Queen and Prince Philip visited our miniature LEGO Buckingham Palace in Miniland back in 2003, so we thought it was only right to wish the Duke of Edinburgh a very happy retirement by marking the occasion in Miniland in our own LEGOLAND way.'\n\nThe 96-year-old Duke may still accompany the Queen to certain events from time to time, but his own diary of royal engagements will end.\n\nHis decision to retire was not medically related and was fully supported by his wife.\n\nPhilip has supported the Queen in her role as head of state for more than 65 years, alongside attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nTheresa May said he had given the Queen 'steadfast support' and Jeremy Corbyn added that his 'clear sense of {"categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges_and_Universities", "label": "dmoz/Reference/Education/Colleges and Universities", "id": 143, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death", "id": 926, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/Death_Care", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/Death Care", "id": 927, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "metro.co.uk", "id": "218", "title": "Metro.co.uk"}, "uri": "702995124", "body": "Here's what will happen when Prince Philip dies Ashitha Nagesh for Metro.co.ukWednesday 2 Aug 2017 12:01 pm Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nThe Telegraph just accidentally published a pre-written obituary for Prince Philip.\n\nThe story had the headline 'HOLD HOLD HOLD Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, dies aged XX'.\n\nThis means someone forgot to 'hold hold hold' and inadvertently announced the Duke's death at the surprisingly young age of 20.\n\nSomeone at the @Telegraph is about to have a very bad day #PrincePhilip pic.twitter.com/fx6OlQA1Hi\n\n-- Rachel Anderson (@randerssays) August 2, 2017\n\nFortunately the Duke of Edinburgh hasn't passed away - he is still very much with us, and is in good health at the age of 96.\n\nHe is elsewhere in the news, however, because today is his last day of royal duties before his retirement officially begins.\n\nBut, while it's morbid, his death will one day be upon us - and it's important that the nation knows what will happen when it does.\n\nHow will we find out?\n\nWhen the Duke of Edinburgh does pass away, the news will likely be shared with the BBC first.\n\nThis will be at 8am GMT if he dies overnight.\n\nWill he have a state funeral?\n\nAs the Queen's consort, Prince Philip is entitled to a full state funeral - but he has previously said that he doesn't want the 'fuss'.\n\nHere's what would happen when the Queen dies\n\nThe Palace of Westminster is always on six-hour notice to prepare Westminster Hall for a lying-in-state ceremony, according to the Times - but authorities have been told that this will not be necessary for Prince Philip.\n\nInstead, it's believed his body will lie at St James's Palace - which is where Princess Diana lay for several days before her funeral 10 years ago.\n\nAnd the funeral itself will likely be low-key, with a service at St George's Chapel in Windsor Castle. Only the Duke's family, friends and heads of state from Commonwealth countries will be in attendance.\n\nWill we be able to view his body before the burial?\n\nNo. The public will not be allowed to see the body while it is lying at St James's.\n\nWhere will he be buried?\n\nThe Duke would be buried in the grounds of Windsor Castle - specifically, in Frogmore Gardens.\n\nWhile most monarchs are buried in Westminster Abbey and St George's Chapel, Prince Philip would be joining Queen Victoria and Prince Albert in Frogmore Gardens, where they are buried in a mausoleum.\n\nWill there be a mourning period?\n\nYes. If the Queen survives Prince Philip, she will enter into an official eight-day period of mourning.\n\nDuring these eight days, laws will not be given the Royal Assent. State affairs will also be put on hold, out of respect.\n\nA further period of official Royal Mourning will then continue for 30 days.\n\nOnly after this month will the bereaved Queen make a full namely the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Cambridge - to support her in her role.\n\nWilliam's job as an air ambulance pilot finished at the end of July - neatly timed for him to become a full-time royal just before his grandfather retires.\n\nThe Queen rarely carries out overseas duties and, although she still holds investitures, a number are also carried out by Charles, William and the Princess Royal.\n\nBuckingham Palace confirmed: ''Her Majesty will continue to carry out a full programme of official engagements with the support of members of the Royal Family.''\n\nPhilip, however, may pop up at public events from time to time.\n\nREAD MORE: New dig at castle where Mary Queen of Scots was held for 14 years\n\nHe could choose to make appearances on the Palace balcony for Trooping the Colour in future years or even turn up to greet US president Donald Trump during his proposed state visit.\n\nIn 1992, the Queen dismissed any speculation that she would step down, insisting frankly: ''It is a job for life.''\n\nShe was speaking about the death of her father, King George VI, for a BBC TV documentary, Elizabeth R, marking the 40th anniversary of her accession.\n\n''In a way, I didn't have an apprenticeship. My father died much too young and so it was all very sudden ... taking on and making the best job you can,'' the Queen said.\n\n''It's a question of maturing into something that one's got used to doing, and accepting the fact that it's your fate, because I think continuity is very important. {"categories": [], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "popsugar.com", "id": "1481", "title": "POPSUGAR Fashion"}, "uri": "703277970", "body": "Prince Philip and Queen Elizabeth II are coming up on 70 years of marriage in November, and while that's a huge feat in itself, the journey to get there hasn't been all that easy for him. Philip -- who is Elizabeth's third cousin -- was originally born Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark, but when he and Elizabeth decided to tie the knot in November 1947, he had to renounce both of his Greek and Danish titles on the morning of his wedding. As a result, Elizabeth's father, King George VI, made him the Duke of Edinburgh. Philip also switched to Anglicanism from Greek Orthodoxy to win the British public's favor and prove his allegiance to Elizabeth.\n\nWhen the king's health began to worsen in 1951, Philip abandoned his naval career to support Elizabeth and assume his royal duties. Philip had just acquired the title of commander of the Royal Navy at the time. \"I don't know how difficult it was, it was naturally disappointing,\" he said in a May 2011 interview with ITV. \"I had just been promoted to commander and the fact was that the most interesting part of my naval career was just starting.\"\n\nElizabeth eventually returned Philip's royal status in 1957 when she gave him the title of a Prince of the United Kingdom, and for his 90th birthday in June 2011, Elizabeth made Philip the head of the Royal Navy, giving him the title and office of Lord High Admiral of the Navy, a position Elizabeth held since 1964. In November 1947, the two made things official when they tied the knot during a luxurious ceremony at Westminster Abbey. Nearly a year after their wedding day, Elizabeth gave birth to the couple's first child, Prince Charles, and they welcomed their daughter, Princess Anne, two years later. Over the years, the pair have shared a number of sweet moments together as they carry out their royal duties across the globe. {"categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Christianity", "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Christianity", "id": 253, "wgt": 100}], "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "id": "16", "title": "The Sun"}, "uri": "702999150", "body": "Ancient rules regarding the Royal succession were scrapped by British Commonwealth countries in 2011\n\nPRINCE Harry says no member of the Royal family wants to become monarch after his grandmother, but they would take the throne for the \"greater good\".\n\nHere we explain who will become the next King after Queen Elizabeth and how the process of Royal succession works after major changes came into place six years ago.\n\nThe throne will pass to Prince Charles if the Queen abdicates, retires or dies.\n\nNext in line would be Charles' eldest son Prince William, the Duke of Cambridge, and his children Prince George and Princess Charlotte.\n\nThe next King or Queen will be the 42nd monarch to reign since William the Conqueror of Normandy obtained the English crown following the Battle of Hastings in 1066.\n\nThe rules of Royal succession have changed significantly in recent years.\n\nLeaders of 16 British Commonwealth countries (including Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Jamaica) voted in 2011 to alter the centuries old tradition to include daughters as well as sons.\n\nPreviously daughters could only inherit the thrones if there were no living sons.\n\nThis system which dated back 300 years is based on the rules of primogeniture which gives preference to the first born male heirs of a king or queen.\n\nThis change in Royal succession means Princess Charlotte, as William and Kate's daughter, is ahead of Prince Harry in the line of succession.\n\nThe oldest male heir and his oldest male child - and their sons and daughters - still take priority in the Royal succession.\n\nCommonwealth leaders also decided in 2011 to remove the rule that no heir could assume the throne if he or she were married to a Roman Catholic.\n\nThen Prime Minister David Cameron said at the time: \"The idea that a younger son should become Monarch instead of an elder daughter, simply because he is a man just isn't acceptable any more.\n\n\"Nor does it make any sense that a potential Monarch can marry someone of any faith other than Catholic.\n\n\"The thinking behind these rules is wrong.\"\n\nThe Roman Catholic rule can be traced to the 16th century reign of Henry VIII.\n\nThe King broke with the Roman Catholic Church to divorce his wife, Queen Catherine, and marry Anne Boleyn.\n\nThe changes, under the Succession to the Crown Act 2013, came into force in March 2015 but apply to people born after October 28 2011.\n\nLive Science reported because one of the duties of the British monarch is to head the Church of England, no Roman Catholic can hold the crown.\n\nThe basis for the succession was determined in the 17th century.\n\nWhen James II fled the country in 1688, Parliament held that he had \"abdicated the government\" and that the throne was vacant.\n\nThe throne was then offered, not to James's young son, but to his daughter Mary and her husband William of Orange, as joint rulers, following the \"Glorious Revolution\".\n\nAt 68-years-old, Prince Charles is the longest serving heir in UK history - having been first in line from the age of three - and would become the oldest ever British monarch to take the throne.\n\nSome Royalists have argued that Prince Charles should step aside to allow Prince William - who celebrated his 35th birthday on June 21 - to become King because he enjoys better approval ratings with the public based on a poll last year.\n\nPrince Charles has faced controversy over his divorce from Princess Diana and his affair during their marriage with wife Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall.\n\nHe has also been accused of \"meddling\" in politics by stating his opinion on issues like the environment and farming, alternative medicine and architecture in private letters to Government ministers.\n\nIn 1936, Edward VIII - the Queen's uncle - famously abdicated after less than a year on the throne so he could marry divorcee Wallis Simpson.\n\nPrince Harry says no Royal wants to be King or Queen -- but they would do it for \"the greater good\".\n\nThe 32-year-old said: \"Is there any one of the Royal Family who wants to be king or queen?\n\n\"I don't think so, but we will carry out our duties at the right time.\"\n\nHarry revealed that the younger Royals wanted to \"carry on the positive atmosphere that the Queen has achieved for over 60 years, but we won't be trying to fill her boots\".\n\nHe told Newsweek magazine: \"We are involved in modernising the British monarchy. We are not doing this for ourselves but for the greater good of the people.\"\n\nAnd he insisted the Royals were still vital, adding: \"We don't want to dilute the magic.\n\n\"The British public and the whole world need institutions like it.\"\n\nThe long-serving royal is stepping back from a public role after 65 years of Royal duties.\n\nHis final solo engagement is The Captain General's Parade on August 2 when he will salute the Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace.\n\nDue to English common laws, he cannot become king.\n\nThe wife of a king is known as a \"Queen Consort\", and takes the title of Queen - although she doesn't rule as the monarch.\n\nBut if a female royal marries a man with a title below her own - as in the case of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip - she will retain the title while her husband will not be entitled to it.", "eventUri": "eng-3330847", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2017-08-02", "title": "Who will be the next King when the Queen dies and will Charles take the While he may show up from time to time alongside the Queen at events if he so desires, he will not be making any solo appearances. (\"Finally, now I have time to watch this show Younger I keep hearing about with that Hilary Duff in it!\" we are sure were his first words upon returning to the palace afterward.)\n\nTo mark the occasion, the Royal Mint is celebrating with . . . a special Prince Philip coin! The \u00a35 coin -- seen here -- features Philip's face on one side and the Queen's on the other (the Queen's face isn't there just for the romantic flourish of having the partners be on either side, but rather because the Queen's face must be on all coinage). On Philip's side of the coin are the words \"Non sibi sed patriae,\" which translate to \"not for self but country\" in Latin (not to \"Prince George is my great-grandson, y'all,\" as we'd been hoping).\n\nPrince Charles himself arrived to help make the coins when he visited the Royal Mint in Wales last month. \"We are particularly delighted that the Prince of Wales struck the very first of the coins that will celebrate the contribution that the Duke of Edinburgh has made to public life,\" Royal Mint Chief Executive Adam Lawrence said.\n\nAs People points out, while Philip receiving his own coin is not particularly out of the ordinary, given it is \"standard fare for milestone royal occasions,\" there is a sweet sort of resonance here as Philip served as the president of the Royal Now they are complaining they are unemployed\".\n\nThe comment unsurprisingly irritated a few people who thought he shouldn't be making lighthearted remarks about mass unemployment.\n\nDS\n\nPrince Philip's most OUTRAGEOUS gaffes: Did he REALLY say these things? Prince Philip, the Queen's husband (or \"consort\" to give him his official title) and Duke of Edinburgh is attending his last event on official business -- a royal marines' charity parade -- before retiring at the age of 96.\n\nBut while the moment will bring welcome respite to a man who recently joked that he \"can't stand up much longer\" and who has served in his role for longer than anyone else in British history, it will mean extra work for the younger royals. Particularly Prince Charles, first in line to the throne, and his son William, the next in the order of succession.\n\nThere is, says royal expert Richard Fitzwilliams, \"a new generation coming into play and taking over the activities of the older.\" Philip, he says, plans to remain attached to all the organizations he currently has a formal relationship with -- well over 700 -- and younger royals may need to fill in for him at their functions.\n\nDaily Emails and Alerts - Get the best of Newsweek delivered to your inbox\n\nMeanwhile the Queen, who is 91, is understood to have no plans to retire, but has already begun delegating some duties to Charles and the other royals. Charles is set to attend the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia, while William is moving his family to London permanently and finishing his job as an air ambulance pilot in order to take on more duties.\n\nFor Charles, taking on greater visibility may serve another function, too: It may not be long before the throne passes to him, and the more chances for positive appearances before the British public, the better. \"We know the Queen will never abdicate, but it only makes sense to adjust things gradually,\" says Fitzwilliams \"to give Charles a higher profile.\"\n\nMeanwhile, for the next generation of royals, the increased acitivity will bring more chances to promote their chosen causes. William, his wife Kate, and Prince Harry have all used their platforms to champion mental health awareness and other issues. The three are particularly well known on the world stage, while Harry's support for the Invictus Games, a Paralympics-style sporting event for wounded or sick armed forces personnel, has introduced him to a new audience.\n\nAnd as for the Duke of Edinburgh himself? \"I think we'll be seeing quite a lot of him,\" says Fitzwilliam, \"When the Duke does appear in the future... there'll be an extra His family comes from the Danish-German house of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glucksburg and many of his relatives became members of the Greek, Norwegian and Danish royal families.\n\nPrince Philip, who turned 96 yesterday, pictured at age 9 when he was Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark, wearing Greek national costume. pic.twitter.com/DePIawOQMR -- Mark (@markuslynnus)\n\nJune 11, 2017\n\nHis mother Princess Alice was German was by birth, but she diplomatically anglicized her surname, changing it from Battenberg to Mountbatten during World War One, as her family had by then moved to Britain.\n\nIn 1930 she was diagnosed with schizophrenia and was moved to a sanatorium in Switzerland, but in later life she lived in London's Buckingham Palace.\n\nPhilip's father was the brother of King Constantine of Greece, but Philip had to renounce his Greek citizenship - as well as his claims to the Danish and Greek thrones - before marrying into Britain's royal family.\n\nCuriously, he told his biographer Fiammetta Rocco in 1992 that \"if anything, I've thought of myself as Scandinavian. Particularly, Danish.\"\n\nProud of my Uncle Greek borne #PrincePhilip who dedicated his life to service of the Queen & her nation Thank you for your dedication at 96 pic.twitter.com/fDuitgWBQ0 -- Prince Pavlos of Gr (@pavlosgr1)\n\nMay 4, 2017\n\nWhen Elizabeth took the throne there was a big debate over what the royal family's surname should be. The queen wanted \"Mountbatten-Windsor\", but former prime minister and war hero Winston Churchill pushed for just \"Windsor\". Churchill had taken a dislike to Louis Mountbatten whom he blamed for losing India as a colony in 1947 and so the royal family became the \"House of Windsor.\"\n\nPhilip's unfortunate gaffes\n\nPhilip remains notorious for his public gaffes, delighting some of his British subjects and horrifying others.\n\nMost recently he lost his patience in 2015, telling an RAF photographer at an event to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain to \"just take the f***ing picture.\"\n\nHis legendary racist comments have often reminded Britons that he hails from an earlier and very different era when Britain still retained colonies across the world.\n\nOn a state visit to China in 1986 he told British students: \"If you stay here much longer, you'll all be slitty-eyed.\"\n\nThen in Australia in 2002 he told an Aboriginal businessman \"Do you still throw spears at each other?\"\n\nVisiting a hospital in 2013 he told a nurse of Filipino origin: \"The Philippines must be half empty as you're all here running the NHS.\"\n\nBack in 1961 he became president of the World Wildlife Fund in 1961 - and shot a tiger in India the same year.\n\nBut, being the Queen's husband he's somehow got away with the dozen or so foot-in-mouth moments during a career that has featured more than 22,000 public engagements since 1952.\n\nCareer highs and lows\n\nPhilip began writing to his future wife when she was just 13 and he's now the longest-serving consort - or spouse - of a reigning British monarch. (The Queen meanwhile is the longest serving head of state in the world today.)\n\nHe's a patron of around 780 organisations and his salary is 401,000 euros a year.\n\nOn ceremonial occasions he's had to walk behind his wife - and not alongside her - because she's the queen and he is merely her consort.\n\nHe's visited 143 countries as well as the Antarctic.\n\nAfter Philip's daughter-in-law the "18894", "title": "Metro Newspaper UK"}, "uri": "702991366", "body": "THE Duke of Edinburgh will carry out his final public engagement before formally retiring from public life as he attends a parade to mark the finale of the Royal Marines 1664 Global Challenge.\n\nThe Queen's Consort announced in May he would be retiring from royal engagements after more than 65 years supporting the monarch in her role as head of state and attending events for his own charities and organisations.\n\nPhilip, 96, was praised at the time for his public service with prime pinister Theresa May leading the tributes saying he had given the Queen 'steadfast support', while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said the Duke's 'clear sense of public duty' had inspired people for more than 60 years.\n\nDespite his age Philip's decision -- which was fully supported by the Queen and was not medically related -- came as a surprise as he still appeared to relish meeting people and carrying out his public role.\n\nThe Duke is known for his quips and over the past few months has been joking about his impending retirement, even telling celebrity cook Prue Leith at a Palace event 'I'm discovering what it's like to be on your last legs'.\n\nBuckingham Palace has stressed although the Duke's diary of engagements will come to an end on Wednesday he may decide to attend certain events, alongside the Queen, from time to time.\n\n\u25a0 A report by the Institute for Fiscal Studies will study how increasing the state pension age for women from 60 to 63 has affected the public coffers and women in that age group.\n\n\u25a0 A piece by leading physician Professor Dominic Wilkinson that grapples with the tragic case of baby Charlie Gard will appear in the British Medical Journal (BMJ). It will look at the nature of public opinion that surrounded the clash between Charlie's parents and Great Ormond Street Hospital and will offer suggestions for a more balanced discussion across the board in future.\n\n\u25a0 Another piece in the BMJ will look at how educating the public to act quickly after an acid attack can minimise injury and significantly improve outcomes for victims.\n\n\u25a0 Chancellor Philip Hammond is in Buenos Aires, Argentina, where he is scheduled to meet with president Mauricio Macri.\n\n\u25a0 The Office for National Statistics releases 2016 statistics on deaths related to drug poisoning in England and Wales.\n\n\u25a0 British multinational defence, aerospace and security company BAE -- which employs 33,000 people in the UK -- will reveal its half-year results\n\n\u25a0 It will be Earth Overshoot Day -- the point of the year in which humans exhaust nature's budget for the year. According to the Global Footprint Network for the rest of the year we will be maintaining our ecological deficit by drawing down local resource stocks and accumulating carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.\n\n\u25a0 It will also be Playday -- a national day of play which celebrates the importance of play to a child's development and includes a national initiative in London.\n\n\u25a0 At
